original: ākampakāni śirasaś ca mahākavīnāṃ teṣāṃ samuccayam anargham ahaṃ vidhāsye // / //🔽Sbhsu /ā / / Subhāṣ / Vvām ad / / /

translated: I shall compose an invaluable collection of those great poets whose works shake the heads (of their rivals).🔽[Sanskrit text for this chapter is available]

original: sugatavrajyā
analyzed: sugata vrajyā
translated: The Chapter on the Well-Gone One

original: ābāhūdgatamaṇḍalāgrarucayaḥ saṃnaddhavakṣaḥsthalāḥ soṣmāṇo vraṇino vipakṣahṛdayapronmāthinaḥ karkaśāḥ /
analyzed: ā bāhu udgata maṇḍala agra rucayaḥ saṃnaddha vakṣaḥ sthalāḥ sa ūṣmāṇaḥ vraṇinaḥ vipakṣa hṛdaya pronmāthinaḥ karkaśāḥ
translated: With the tips of their halos rising up to their shoulders, their chests armored, with fever, wounded, harsh, causing agitation in the hearts of their enemies,

original: utsṛṣṭāmbaradṛṣṭavigrahabharā yasya smarāgresarā mārā māravadhūstanāś ca na dadhuḥ kṣobhaṃ sa vo 'vyāj jinaḥ // / //
analyzed: utsṛṣṭa ambara dṛṣṭa vigraha bharāḥ yasya smara agresarāḥ mārāḥ māra vadhū stanāḥ ca na kṣobham sa vaḥ jinaḥ  /
translated: Whose foremost enemies, abandoning their bodies visible in the sky, and the breasts of Mara's wives, did not experience agitation, may that Jina protect you all.

original: aśvaghoṣasya
analyzed: aśvaghoṣasya
translated: Of Ashvaghosa

original: namrāḥ pādanakheṣu yasya daśasu brahmeśakṛṣṇāstraya ste devāḥ pratibimbanās tridaśatāṃ suvyaktam āpedire /
analyzed: namrāḥ pāda nakheṣu yasya daśasu brahma īśa kṛṣṇāḥ trayaḥ te devāḥ pratibimbanāḥ tridaśa tām su vyaktam āpedire
translated: The three gods Brahma, Ishvara, and Krishna, bowing at his ten toenails, clearly attained the state of being gods.

original: sa trailokyaguruḥ sudustarabhavākūpārapāraṅgato māravyūhajayapragalbhasubhaṭaḥ śāstā tava stān mude // / //
analyzed: sa trailokya guruḥ sudustara bhava akūpāra pāraṅgataḥ māra vyūha jaya pragalbha su bhaṭaḥ śāstā tava stād mude
translated: He, the guru of the three worlds, who has gone beyond the ocean of existence so difficult to cross, the conqueror, the bold warrior who has defeated Mara's army, may that Buddha be for your joy.

original: vasukalpasya
analyzed: vasukalpasya
translated: Of Vasukalpa

original: kāmakrodhau dvayam api yadi pratyanīkaṃ prasiddhaṃ hatvānaṅgaṃ kim iva hi ruṣā sādhitaṃ tryambakena /
analyzed: kāma krodhau dvayam api yadi pratyanīkam prasiddham hatvā anaṅgam kim iva hi ruṣā sādhitam tryambakena
translated: If both desire and anger are well-known to be mutually opposed, then what was accomplished by Shiva through anger after killing Ananga (Cupid)?

original: yas tu kṣāntyā śamayati śataṃ manmathādīnarātīn kalyāṇaṃ vo diśatu sa munigrāmaṇīr arkabandhuḥ // / //
analyzed: yaḥ tu kṣāntyā śamayati śatam manmatha ādīn arātīn kalyāṇam vaḥ diśatu sa muni grāmaṇīḥ arkabandhuḥ
translated: May that sage, the friend of the sun, the chief of sages, who pacifies with forbearance the hundred enemies of men, such as lust and so on, direct you to what is wholesome.

original: saṅghaśriyaḥ / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: saṅgha śriyaḥ
translated: Of Saṅghaśrī.

original: śreyāṃsi vaḥ sa sugataḥ kurutād apāra saṃsārasāgarasamuttaraṇaikasetuḥ /
analyzed: śreyāṃsi vaḥ sa sugataḥ kurutāt apāra saṃsāra sāgara samuttaraṇa eka setuḥ
translated: May that Sugata, the sole bridge for crossing the ocean of endless worldly existence, bring you all that is good.

original: durvāramāraparivārabalāvalepa kalpāntasaṃtatapayaḥprasarair ahāryaḥ // / //
analyzed: durvāra māra parivāra bala avalepa kalpa anta saṃtata payaḥ prasaraiḥ a hāryaḥ
translated: He who is unmoved by the irresistible pride of strength of the retinue of Māra, by the continuous flow of water at the end of a kalpa.

original: aparājitarakṣitasya
analyzed: aparājita rakṣitasya
translated: Of Aparājita Rāṣṭrapāla.

original: śāstā samastabhuvanaṃ bhagavān apāyāt pāyād apāstatimiro mihiropameyaḥ /
analyzed: śāstā samasta bhuvanam bhagavān apāyāt pāyāt apāsta timiraḥ mihira upameyaḥ
translated: May the Blessed One, the teacher of the entire world, who is like the sun, protect you, dispelling darkness.

original: saṃsārabhittibhiduro bhavakandakandu kandarpadarpadalanavyasanī munīndraḥ // / //
translated: The lord of sages, who splits the walls of saṃsāra, who is the pestle for the bulb of existence, who is devoted to destroying the pride of Kāmadeva.

original: vasukalpasya
analyzed: vasukalpasya
translated: Of Vasukalpa.

original: kāruṇyāmṛtakandalīsumanasaḥ prajñāvadhūmauktika grīvālaṃkaraṇaśriyaḥ śamasaritpūrocchalacchīkarāḥ /
analyzed: kāruṇya amṛta kandalī sumanasaḥ prajñā vadhū mauktika grīvā alaṃkaraṇa śriyaḥ śama sarit pūra ucchalat śīkarāḥ
translated: The flowers of the lotus of compassion, the pearls of the smoke of wisdom, the glory of the necklace of the river of peace, the foam of the rising waves,

original: te maulau bhavatāṃ milantu jagatīrājyābhiṣekocita sragbhedā abhayapradānacaraṇapreṅkhannakhāgrāṃśavaḥ // / //
analyzed: te maulau bhavatām milantu sraj bhedāḥ abhaya pradāna caraṇa preṅkhat nakha agra aṃśavaḥ  /
translated: May those garlands fit for the coronation of the kingdom of the world, the rays of the tips of the toes of the gift of fearlessness, touch your head.

original: Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: skmsauka
translated: Of Saṅghaśrī.

original: śīlāmbhaḥpariṣekaśītaladṛḍhadhyānālavālasphurad dānaskandhamahonnatiḥ pṛthutaraprajñollasatpallavaḥ /
analyzed: śīla ambhaḥ pariṣeka śītala dṛḍha dhyāna ālavāla sphurat dāna skandha mahā unnatiḥ pṛthutara prajñā ullasat pallavaḥ
translated: The tree of enlightenment, with the water of morality as its refreshing irrigation, the trunk of firm meditation, the spreading branches of the great generosity, the abundant foliage of vast wisdom,

original: deyāt tubhyaṃ avārthavīryaviṭapaḥ kṣāntiprasūnodgamaḥ succhāyaḥ ṣaḍabhijñakalpaviṭapīsaṃbodhabījaṃ phalam // / //
analyzed: deyāt tubhyam kṣānti prasūna udgamaḥ su chāyaḥ ṣaḍabhijña kalpa viṭapī saṃbodha bījam phalam
translated: The foliage of forbearance, the flowers of effort, the fruit of the seed of perfect enlightenment, the shade of the six higher knowledges, may it be given to you.

original: etau śrīdharanandinaḥ / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: etau śrīdharanandinaḥ
translated: These two are of Śrīdhara and Nandana.

original: ekasyāpi manobhuvas tadabalāpāṅgair jagannirjaye kāmaṃ nihnutasarvavismayarasavyaktiprakārā vayam /
analyzed: ekasya api manobhuvaḥ tad abala apāṅgaiḥ jagat nirjaye kāmam nihnuta sarva vismaya rasa vyakti prakārāḥ vayam
translated: Even for one mind-born, by her sidelong glances, in the conquest of the world, we are indeed of a kind to conceal all expressions of wonder.

original: yas tv enaṃ sabalaṃ ca jetum abhitas tatkampamātraṃ bhruvo rnārebhe sugatas tu tadguṇakathā stambhāya naḥ kevalam // / //
analyzed: yaḥ tu enam sa balam ca jetum abhitas tad kampa mātram bhruvoḥ na ārebhe sugataḥ tu tad guṇa kathā stambhāya naḥ kevalam  /
translated: But the Sugata, in order to conquer him and his army, merely raised his eyebrows, not to erect us, but only to make a proclamation of his virtues.

original: kumudākaramateḥ //
analyzed: kumuda ākara mateḥ
translated: This is of Kumudākara.

original: pratyekānantajātiprativapur amitāvṛttijanmārijair no bhoktṛvrātojjhihīrṣāphalanilayamahāpauruṣasyāpi śāstuḥ /
analyzed: pratyeka ananta jāti prativapuḥ amita āvṛtti janma ari jaiḥ naḥ bhoktṛ vrāta ujjhihīrṣā phala nilaya mahā pauruṣasya api śāstuḥ
translated: Even for the Teacher, whose great manliness is the abode of the fruit of the desire to abandon the multitude of enjoyers, who has innumerable births in each of the countless past lives,

original: ke 'py utkarṣaṃ stuvanti smaram api jayatas tad vadāmaḥ kim asmin yo bhasmāsīt kaṭākṣajvalanakaṇikayā drāg umākāmukasya // /
analyzed: ke pi utkarṣam stuvanti smaram api jayataḥ tat vadāmaḥ kim asmin yaḥ bhasma āsīt kaṭākṣa jvalana kaṇikayā drāk umā kāmukasya  /
translated: Some praise the superiority of Cupid, who conquered even Śiva. What can be said about him? He was reduced to ashes by the spark of the sidelong glance of Umā's lover.

original: vallaṇasya 🔽pāyād vaḥ samayaḥ sa mārajayino bandhyāyitāstrotkaraḥ krodhād yatra taduttamāṅgakavalonmīlanmahāvikramaḥ /
analyzed: vallaṇasya  pāyāt vaḥ samayaḥ sa māra jayinaḥ bandhyāyita astra utkaraḥ krodhāt yatra tad uttamāṅga kavala unmīlat mahā vikramaḥ
translated: Of Vallabha🔽May that time of Śiva's victory over Cupid, when his arrows became ineffective, protect you all, in which his great valor manifested in devouring the head out of anger,

original: āsīd adbhutamaulir atramilitāṃ vyāttānanacchāyikām ālokyātmana eva mārasumaṭaḥ paryastadhairyodayaḥ // / //🔽khelācañcalasaṃcarannijapadapreṅkholalīlāmilat sadyaḥsāndraparāgarāgaracitāpūrvaprasūnaśriyaḥ /
analyzed: āsīt adbhuta mauliḥ atra militām vyātta ānana chāyikām ālokya ātmanaḥ eva māra sumaṭaḥ paryasta dhairya udayaḥ  /   khelā cañcala saṃcarat nija pada preṅkhola līlā milat sadyas sāndra parāga rāga racita apūrva prasūna śriyaḥ
translated: When the god of love, seeing the shadow of the wide-open mouth of Śiva, who had assumed a wonderful form, became united with his own self, and his rising steadfastness was overturned.🔽The cluster of flowers, which is a collection of flowers newly created with intense color by the playful, swaying, and moving of the bees greedy for embracing each other,

original: āśliṣyanmadhulampaṭālinivahasyoccair mithaś cumbanair vyākoṣaḥ kusumāñjalir diśatu vaḥ śreyo nijāyārpitaḥ // / //
analyzed: āśliṣyat madhu lampaṭa ali nivahasya uccais mithas cumbanaiḥ vyākoṣaḥ kusumāñjaliḥ diśatu vaḥ śreyaḥ nijāya arpitaḥ  /
translated: Which is opened by the high mutual kisses of the flock of bees eager for honey, and offered to his own self, may it bestow well-being upon you.

original: jitārinandinaḥ
analyzed: jita ari nandinaḥ
translated: Of Jitāri-nandana

original: daronmuktāraktasphuradadharavīthīkramavaman mayūkhāntarmūrcchaddyutidaśanam uddeśavaśinaḥ /
analyzed: dara unmukta ārakta sphurat adhara vīthī krama vaman mayūkha antar mūrcchat dyuti daśanam uddeśa vaśinaḥ
translated: With the row of lips throbbing with released passion, the radiance of the teeth fainting within the rays, of the one who is the lord of the directions,

original: sukhaṃ tad vaḥ śāstur diśatu śivam ajñānarajanī vyavacchedodgacchan mahimaghanasaṃdhyātapa iva // / //
analyzed: sukham tat vaḥ śāstuḥ diśatu śivam ajñāna rajanī vyavaccheda udgacchan mahima ghana saṃdhyā ātapaḥ iva  /
translated: May that happiness grant you the auspiciousness of the teacher, like the rising twilight glow of the great glory of the dispelling of the night of ignorance.

original: trilocanasya
analyzed: tri locanasya
translated: Of Trilocana.

original: kandarpād api sundarākṛtir iti prauḍhotsaladrāgayā vṛddhatvaṃ varayoṣito 'nayad iti trāsākulasvāntayā /
analyzed: kandarpāt api sundara ākṛtiḥ iti prauḍha utsalat rāgayā vṛddha tvam vara yoṣitaḥ nayat iti trāsa ākula svāntayā
translated: With intense passion, thinking Your form is more beautiful than even Cupid's, and with a mind troubled by fear, thinking You have brought the most excellent woman to old age,

original: mārasyāpi śarair abhedyahṛd iti śraddhābharaprahvayā pāyād vaḥ sphuṭabāṣpakampapulakaṃ ratyā jino vanditaḥ // / //
analyzed: mārasya api śaraiḥ abhedya hṛt iti śraddhā bhara prahvayā pāyāt vaḥ sphuṭa bāṣpa kampa pulakam ratyā jinaḥ vanditaḥ  /
translated: And with deep devotion, thinking Your heart is unpierced by even Mara's arrows, may the Jina, worshipped by Rati with tears, trembling, and horripilation, protect you all.

original: tasyaiveti śrutiḥ 🔽pādāmbhojasamīpasannipatitasvarṇāthadehasphuran netrastomatayā parisphuṭamilannīlābjapūjāvidhiḥ /
analyzed: tasya eva iti śrutiḥ
translated: Of him alone, thus is the scripture.🔽With the shining eyes of the golden swan that has approached the lotus feet, the worship of the blue lotus is clearly accomplished.

original: vandārutridaśaudharatramukuṭotsarpatprabhāpallava pratyunmīladapūrvacīvarapaṭaḥ śākyo muniḥ pātu vaḥ // / //
analyzed: vandāru tridaśa audhara tra mukuṭa utsarpat prabhā pallava pratyunmīlat apūrva cīvara paṭaḥ śākyaḥ muniḥ pātu vaḥ  /
translated: May the Shakyamuni Sage, with the spreading rays of the crowns of the gods of the three worlds, and the unfolding of the new robe, protect you all.

original: vasukalpasya / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: vasu kalpasya skmsauka
translated: Of Vasukalpa.

original: ka ekas tvaṃ puṣpāyudha mama samādhivyayavidhau suparvāṇaḥ sarve yadi kusumaśastrās tad api kim /
analyzed: kaḥ ekaḥ tvam puṣpāyudha mama samādhi vyaya vidhau su parvāṇaḥ sarve yadi kusuma śastrāḥ tat api kim
translated: O single one, O flower-weaponed one, if all the well-jointed arrows are indeed flower-weapons, then what is it that destroys my concentration?

original: itīvainān nūnaṃ ya iha sumano 'stratvam anayat sa vaḥ śāstā śastraṃ diśatu daśadiṅmāravijayī // / //
analyzed: iti iva enān nūnam yaḥ iha su mano stra tvam anayat sa vaḥ śāstā śastram diśatu daśa diś māra vijayī  /
translated: Thus, indeed, he who has brought you here to the state of being a good weapon, may that teacher of yours, victorious over the ten directions, bestow the weapon upon you.

original: iti sugatavrajyā ////
analyzed: iti sugata vrajyā
translated: Thus ends the chapter on Sugata.

original: tato lokeśvaravrajyā
analyzed: tatas lokeśvara vrajyā
translated: Then begins the chapter on Lokeswara.

original: dyutisvacchajyotsnāpaṭapaṭalavṛṣṭyā na kamalaṃ na candraḥ sāndraśrīparimalagarimṇāsyam amalam /
analyzed: dyuti svaccha jyotsnā paṭa paṭala vṛṣṭyā na kamalam na candraḥ sāndra śrī parimala garimṇā āsyam amalam
translated: By the rain of the thick clear moonlight of his radiance, neither the lotus nor the moon, his spotless face with the weight of intense beauty and fragrance,

original: madhūdrāṇāṃ nidrābhiduram apamudrādbhutamudaś cakorān bibhrāṇaṃ sarasiruhapāṇer avatu vaḥ // / //
analyzed: madhūdrāṇām nidrā bhiduram apamudrā adbhuta mudaḥ cakorān bibhrāṇam sarasiruha pāṇeḥ avatu vaḥ  /
translated: bearing the cakoras whose sleep is dispelled by the nectar-dripping lotus in his hand, may that Lokeswara protect you all.

original: buddhākaraguptasya / Skmsa /u /ka / /
analyzed: buddha ākaraguptasya
translated: Of Buddhakaragupta. Skm. U. K.

original: varadakarasarojasyandamānāmṛtaugha vyupaśamitasamastapretasaṃghātatarṣaḥ /
analyzed: vara da kara saroja syandamāna amṛta ogha vyupaśamita samasta preta saṃghāta tarṣaḥ
translated: The stream of nectar flowing from the lotus hand of the bestower of boons, quenching the thirst of the entire host of pretas,

original: jayati sitagabhastistomaśubhrānanaśrīḥ sahajagurudayārdrālokano lokanāthaḥ // / //
analyzed: jayati sita gabhasti stoma śubhra ānana śrīḥ sahaja guru dayā ārdra ālokanaḥ lokanāthaḥ  /
translated: Victorious is the Lord of the World, his face shining white like the splendor of the white rays, his gaze moist with affection for the rising Guru by nature.

original: ratnakīrteḥ
analyzed: ratnakīrteḥ
translated: Of Ratnakirti.

original: atyudgāḍharayasthirākṛtighanadhvānabhramanmandara kṣubdhakṣīradhivīcisaṃcayagataprāleyapādopamaḥ /
analyzed: ati udgāḍha raya sthira ākṛti ghana dhvāna bhramat mandara kṣubdha kṣīradhi vīci saṃcaya gata prāleya pāda upamaḥ
translated: Resembling a mass of snow fallen into the waves of the churned milk ocean, with the deep, loud, continuous sound of the churning Mandara mountain,

original: śrīmatpotalake gabhīravivṛtidhvānapratidhvānite sāndrasvāṃśucayaśriyā valayito lokeśvaraḥ pātu vaḥ // / //
analyzed: śrīmat potalake gabhīra vivṛti dhvāna pratidhvānite sāndra sva aṃśu caya śriyā valayitaḥ lokeśvaraḥ pātu vaḥ  /
translated: On the glorious Pota(la) mountain, resounding with the echoes of profound explanations, may the Lord of the World, surrounded by the splendor of his dense rays, protect you all.

original: jñānaśrīmitrasya
analyzed: jñāna śrī mitrasya
translated: Of Jñānaśrīmitra

original: kṛpāvṛṣṭisphūtāt tava hṛdayapīyūṣasarasaḥ pravāho nirgatya kramatanimaramyaḥ karuṇayā /
analyzed: kṛpā vṛṣṭi sphūtāt tava hṛdaya pīyūṣa sarasaḥ pravāhaḥ nirgatya krama tanima ramyaḥ karuṇayā
translated: The stream flowing out from the nectar lake of your heart, swollen by the rain of compassion, gradually becoming delightful through compassion,

original: tṛṣārtānām īṣad vitataṃ adharāntaḥ prati gati praṇālībhiḥ pañcābhavad iti kiṃ anyad bhujakarāt // / //
analyzed: tṛṣā ārtānām īṣat vitatam adhara antar prati praṇālībhiḥ pañca abhavat iti kim anyat bhuja karāt  /
translated: The little water flowing into the mouths of the thirsty through the channels, became five - what else is there but the arm of a benefactor?

original: trilocanasya 🔽ravim iva dhṛtāmitābhaṃ kavim iva surasārthaviracitastotram /
analyzed: tri locanasya  ravim iva dhṛta amita ābham kavim iva su rasa artha viracita stotram
translated: Of Trilocana🔽I praise the Lord of the Khasa people, who is like the sun with immeasurable splendor, like a poet whose praise is composed by the assembly of good people,

original: madhum iva saṃbhṛtakaruṇaṃ vidhum iva nāthaṃ khasarpaṇaṃ vande // / //
analyzed: madhum iva saṃbhṛta karuṇam vidhum iva nātham kha sarpaṇam vande  /
translated: Like honey with accumulated compassion, like the moon, the Lord.

original: puruṣottamasya
analyzed: puruṣottamasya
translated: Of Puruṣottama

original: udarasyedam aṇutvaṃ sahajagurutvaṃ yadi nedaṃ hṛdayasya /
analyzed: udarasya idam aṇu tvam sahaja guru tvam yadi nā idam hṛdayasya
translated: If this is not the smallness of the stomach and the natural heaviness of the heart,

original: svārthe katham alasatvaṃ katham anusatvaṃ hitakaraṇe matir asya // / //
analyzed: sva arthe katham alasa tvam katham hita karaṇe matiḥ asya  /
translated: How is it that he is lazy in his own interest and has a mind to do good to others?

original: jñānaśrīmitrasya
analyzed: jñāna śrī mitrasya
translated: Of Jñānaśrīmitra

original: vaktraṃ naiṣa kalānidhir dhavalimā naiṣojjvalā kaumudī netre nīrarucī na lāñchanayugaṃ candre 'sty amandacchavi /
analyzed: vaktram nā eṣa kalā nidhiḥ dhavalimā nā eṣā ujjvalā kaumudī netre nīra rucī na lāñchana yugam candre sti amanda chavi
translated: This is not the moon, a treasure of arts; this is not the bright moonlight; these eyes are not charming with water; and the moon has not a dark spot of deep luster.

original: ity unnīya vidhor abhītivihasad yat saṃnidhiṃ sādhvagān nūnaṃ nīrajam astu vaḥ śivadive tad lokanāthānanam // / //
analyzed: iti unnīya vidhoḥ abhīti vihasat yat saṃnidhim sādhu agāt nūnam nīrajam astu vaḥ śiva dive tat lokanātha ānanam  /
translated: Thus, having understood the moon's fear of the sun, the good people have approached the presence of the Lord of the World, laughing. Let that lotus face of the Lord of the World be auspicious to you on this day.

original: jaṭājūṭābhyantarnavaravir iva śyāmajalabhṛd vṛtaḥ śoṇāśokastavakam amitābhaḥ praminute /
analyzed: jaṭā jūṭa abhyantar nava raviḥ iva śyāma jalabhṛt vṛtaḥ śoṇa aśoka stavakam amita ābhaḥ praminute
translated: Surrounded by the dark water of the new moon within the matted locks, Amitabha outshines the cluster of red ashoka flowers.

original: maharṣer yasyendudyutighaṭitamūrter iva sa vaḥ klamaṃ bhindyād dadyāt praśamasukhapīyūṣalaharīm // / //
analyzed: mahā ṛṣeḥ yasya indu dyuti ghaṭita mūrteḥ iva sa vaḥ klamam bhindyāt dadyāt praśama sukha pīyūṣa laharīm
translated: May that [Amitabha] break your fatigue, as if he were the sage with a form made of the radiance of the moon, and bestow a wave of the nectar of the bliss of tranquility.

original: buddhākarasyaitau
analyzed: buddha ākarasya etau
translated: These are by Buddhakaraprabha.

original: iti lokeśvaravrajyā ////
analyzed: iti lokeśvara vrajyā
translated: Thus ends the chapter on Lokeśvara.

original: tato mañjughoṣavrajyā🔽aṅgāmodasamocchaladghṛṇipatadbhṛṅgāvalīmālita sphūrjallañchanasūtragumphitamilannīlotpalaśrīr iva /
analyzed: tatas mañjughoṣa vrajyā  aṅga āmoda sama ucchalat ghṛṇi patat bhṛṅga āvalī mālita sphūrjat lañchana sūtra gumphita milat nīlotpala śrīḥ iva
translated: Then begins the chapter on Mañjughosa.🔽Adorned with a garland of bees hovering and falling, intoxicated by the fragrance of the limbs, with the splendor of blue lotuses gathered in the fluttering sash,

original: niryatpādanakhonmukhāṃśuvisarasragdanturaḥ smaryatāṃ mañjuśrīḥ suramuktamañjariśikhāvarṣair ivābhyarcitaḥ // / //
analyzed: niryat pāda nakha unmukha aṃśu visara sraj danturaḥ smaryatām mañjuśrīḥ sura mukta mañjari śikhā varṣaiḥ iva abhyarcitaḥ  /
translated: May Mañjuśrī be remembered, his feet adorned with the rays of light from the tips of the nails, as if worshipped with showers of flower-clusters released by the gods.

original: śastrodyadbāhudehasphuradanalamiladdhūmakalpāntapuñjaḥ śṛṅgāntānantaviśvārpitamahiṣaśiromakṣikālīvikalpaḥ /
translated: With his body's arm raised like a weapon, with a fire-like appearance like the smoke of the end of the world, with the top of his horns like a fly on the head of a buffalo, the infinite universe is offered.

original: trāsatyaktasvaparṇāstṛtasuraghṛṇayevālasatpādavṛndas tāraughapluṣṭabhānur jagad avatu naṭadbhairavātmā kumāraḥ // /
analyzed: trāsa tyakta sva parṇa āstṛta sura ghṛṇayā iva alasat pāda vṛndaḥ tārā ogha pluṣṭa bhānuḥ jagat avatu naṭat bhairava ātmā kumāraḥ  /
translated: With his feet's group moving slowly as if out of shame for the gods' wings abandoned in fear, with the sun scorched by a multitude of stars, may Kumara, the dancer, the essence of Bhairava, protect the world.

original: vallaṇasyaitau
analyzed: vallaṇasya etau
translated: These two are by Vallana.

original: khaḍgī saśabdam atha pustakavān sacintaṃ bālaḥ sakhelam abhirāmatamaḥ sakāmam /
analyzed: khaḍgī sa śabdam atha pustakavān sa cintam bālaḥ sa khelam abhirāmatamaḥ sa kāmam
translated: The sword-bearer with a sound, then the book-bearer with thought, the young boy with play, the most charming one with desire,

original: nānāvidhaṃ suravadhūbhir itīkṣito vaḥ pāyāc ciraṃ sugatavaṃśadharaḥ kumāraḥ // / //
analyzed: nānāvidham sura vadhūbhiḥ iti īkṣitaḥ vaḥ pāyāt ciram sugata vaṃśa dharaḥ kumāraḥ
translated: Seen thus by the divine women in various ways, may the prince, the bearer of the lineage of the Sugatas, protect you all for a long time.

original: puruṣottamasya
analyzed: puruṣottamasya
translated: Of Purushottama

original: mugdhāṅgulīkiśalayāṅghrisuvarṇakumbha vāntena kāntipayasā dhusṛṇāruṇena /
analyzed: mugdha aṅgulī kiśalaya aṅghri suvarṇa kumbha vāntena kānti payasā dhusṛṇa aruṇena
translated: By the golden pitcher of his feet with tender toes, he pours forth the milk of beauty tinged with saffron,

original: yo vandamānam abhiṣiñcati dharmarājye jāgartu vo hitasukhāya sa mañjuvajraḥ // / //
analyzed: yaḥ vandamānam abhiṣiñcati dharma rājye jāgartu vaḥ hita sukhāya sa mañju vajraḥ
translated: Who consecrates the one bowing with the kingdom of Dharma. May that Manjushri protect you all for your welfare and happiness.

original: jitāripādānām
analyzed: jita ari pādānām
translated: Of Jitaripada

original: amīṣāṃ mañjuśrīruciravadanaśrīkṛtarucāṃ śrutaṃ no nāmāpi kva nu khalu himāṃśuprakṛtayaḥ /
analyzed: amīṣām mañjuśrī rucira vadana śrī kṛta rucām śrutam naḥ nāma api kva nu khalu himāṃśu prakṛtayaḥ
translated: We have heard the names of these, who beautify the lovely face of Manjushri, but where are they, whose nature is like the moon?

original: mamābhyarṇe dhārṣṭyāc carati punar indīvaram iti krudhevedaṃ prāntāruṇam avatu vo locanayugam // / //
analyzed: mama abhyarṇe dhārṣṭyāt carati punar indīvaram iti krudhā iva idam prānta aruṇam avatu vaḥ locana yugam
translated: And near me, as if in anger, the blue lotus moves again. May this pair of your eyes, reddened at the edges, protect you.

original: iti mañjughoṣavrajyā ////
analyzed: iti mañjughoṣa vrajyā
translated: Thus ends the chapter on Manjushri.

original: tato maheśvaravrajyā
analyzed: tatas maheśvara vrajyā
translated: Then the chapter on Mahesvara.

original: śilpaṃ trīṇi jaganti yasya kavitā yasya trivedī guror yaś cakre tripuravyayaṃ tripathagā yanmūrdhni mālyāyate /
analyzed: śilpam trīṇi jaganti yasya kavi tā yasya trivedī guroḥ yaḥ cakre tripura vyayam tripathagā yad mūrdhni mālyāyate
translated: Whose art is the three worlds, whose poetry is the three altars of the guru, and who made the destruction of Tripura, on whose head the three-streamed Ganges hangs as a garland,

original: trīn kālān iva vīkṣituṃ vahati yo visphūrjadakṣṇāṃ trayaṃ sa traiguṇyaparicchedo vijayate devas triśūlāyudhaḥ // / //
analyzed: trīn kālān iva vīkṣitum vahati yaḥ visphūrja dakṣṇām trayam sa traiguṇya paricchedaḥ vijayate devaḥ triśūla āyudhaḥ  /
translated: Who bears three eyes as if to behold the three times, and whose loud laughter is the three worlds - may that god, the weapon of the trident, who is beyond the three qualities, be victorious.

original: vasukalpadattasya // Skmsa /u /ka / 🔽vāṇībhūtapurāṇapūruṣadhṛtipratyāśayā dhāvite nidrāti kṣaṇajāśuśukṣaṇikaṇaklānte śakunteśvare /
analyzed: vasukalpadattasya  vāṇī bhūta purāṇa pūruṣa dhṛti pratyāśayā dhāvite kṣaṇaja āśuśukṣaṇi kaṇa klānte śakunteśvare
translated: Of Vasukalpadatta.🔽When the lord of birds, tired by the momentary flashes of lightning, sleeps, hoping to hold the ancient Purusha who has become speech,

original: namronnamrabhujaṅgapuṅgavaguṇavyākṛṣṭabāṇāsana kṣiptāstrasya puradruho vijayate saṃdhānasīmāśramaḥ // / //
analyzed: namra unnamra bhujaṅga puṅgava guṇa vyākṛṣṭa bāṇāsana kṣipta astrasya puradruhaḥ vijayate saṃdhāna sīmā śramaḥ
translated: The hermitage on the border of peace of the one whose weapon has been cast away, the enemy of the cities, whose bow is drawn by the qualities of the serpent king, who is bent and raised, is victorious.

original: murāreḥ / Ar a /rā / / / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: murāreḥ ar arā
translated: Of Murari.

original: pīyūṣadravapānadohadarasavyagroragagrāmaṇī daṣṭaḥ pātu śaśī maheśvaraśiromepathyaratnāṅkuraḥ /
analyzed: pīyūṣa drava pāna dohada rasa vyagra uraga grāmaṇī daṣṭaḥ pātu śaśī maheśvara śiraḥ mepathya ratna aṅkuraḥ
translated: May the moon, the sprout of a jewel of a remedy for the head of Mahesvara, which is busy with the passion of drinking the nectar-fluid, bitten by the chief of the serpents, protect you.

original: yo bimbapratipūraṇāya vidhṛto niṣpīḍya saṃdaṃśikā yantre śaivalalāṭalocanaśikhājvālābhir ābarhyate // / //
analyzed: yaḥ bimba pratipūraṇāya vidhṛtaḥ niṣpīḍya saṃdaṃśikāḥ yantre śaiva lalāṭa locana śikhā jvālābhiḥ ābarhyate  /
translated: Which is held in a pair of tongs to fill the orb, squeezed out, and heated with the flames from the eye on Shiva's forehead in a machine.

original: murārer etau
analyzed: murāreḥ etau
translated: These two of Murari

original: bhadraṃ candrakale śivaṃ suranadi śreyaḥ kapālaāvale kalyāṇaṃ bhujagendravalli kuśalaṃ viśve śaṭāsaṃtate /
analyzed: bhadram candra kale śivam sura nadi śreyaḥ kapāla āvale kalyāṇam bhujaga indra valli kuśalam viśve śaṭā saṃtate
translated: Fortunate, O moon-crested one, auspicious, O god's river, excellent, O row of skulls, well-being, O serpent-chief's creeper, skillful, O universe's mass of light.🔽Thus say these, gathered together, when he, having gone to peace,

original: ity āhur militāḥ parasparam amūr yasmin praśāntiṃ gate kapāntārabhaṭīnaṭasya bhavatāt tad vaḥ śriye tāṇḍavam // / //
analyzed: iti āhuḥ militāḥ parasparam amūḥ yasmin praśāntim gate kapānta ārabhaṭī naṭasya bhavatāt tat vaḥ śriye tāṇḍavam
translated: May the dance of Shiva, the dancer of the battlefield of the end of the world, be for your prosperity.

original: devi tvadvadanopamānasuhṛdām eṣāṃ sarojanmanāṃ paśya vyomani lohitāyati śanair eṣā daśā vartate /
analyzed: devi tvad vadana upamāna suhṛdām eṣām saraḥ janmanām paśya vyomani lohitāyati śanais eṣā daśā vartate
translated: O Goddess, behold this state slowly turning red in the sky of these lotuses, friends of your face.

original: itthaṃ saṃkucadambajānukaraṇavyājopanītāñjaleḥ śambhor vañcitapārvatīkamucitam saṃdhyārcanaṃ pātu vaḥ // / //
analyzed: ittham saṃkucat amba jānu karaṇa vyāja upanīta añjaleḥ śambhoḥ vañcita pārvatīkam ucitam saṃdhyā arcanam pātu vaḥ  /
translated: Thus, with folded hands feigned to imitate the closing lotus, may Shiva's proper worship of the twilight, which deceived Parvati, protect you all.

original: rājaśekharasya
analyzed: rājaśekharasya
translated: Of Rajasekhara

original: kasmāt pārvati niṣṭhurāsi sahaja śailīdbhavānām idaṃ niḥsnehāsi kuto na bhasmaparuṣaḥ snehaṃ kvacin nindati /
analyzed: kasmāt pārvati niṣṭhurā asi sahaja idam niḥsnehā asi kutas na bhasma paruṣaḥ sneham kvacid nindati
translated: O Pārvatī, why are you so harsh? This is the natural style of the gods. Why are you so cold? Where does he not censure love as rough as ashes?

original: kopas te mayi niṣphalaḥ priyatame sthāṇau phalaṃ kiṃ bhaved itthaṃ nirvacanīkṛto dayitayā śambhuḥ śivāyās tu vaḥ // / //
analyzed: kopaḥ te mayi niṣphalaḥ priyatame sthāṇau phalam kim bhavet ittham nirvacanīkṛtaḥ dayitayā śambhuḥ śivāyāḥ tu vaḥ  /
translated: Your anger towards me is fruitless, O beloved. What fruit could there be in an inanimate object? Thus rebuked by his beloved, may Śiva's Śiva be for you all.

original: bhojadevasya Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: bhojadevasya skmsauka
translated: Of Bhoja Devavarma

original: vapuḥ prādurbhāvād anumitam idaṃ janmani purā purāre na prāyaḥ kvacid api bhavantaṃ praṇatavān /
analyzed: vapuḥ prādurbhāvāt anumitam idam janmani purā purāre na prāyas kvacid api bhavantam praṇatavān
translated: O Śiva, in this birth, I have not bowed to you anywhere, O destroyer of the city, because of the manifestation of this body, it is inferred that in previous births, I have not bowed to you.

original: naman janmany asminn aham atanur agre 'py anatibhāṅ maheśa kṣantavyaṃ tad idam aparādhadvayam api // / //
analyzed: naman janmani asmin aham a tanuḥ agre pi an ati bhāj maheśa kṣantavyam tat idam aparādha dvayam api
translated: O Maheśa, in this birth, I am bowing to you, but I am not able to do so fully. Please forgive these two offenses.

original: muñjasya / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: muñjasya skmsauka
translated: Of Muñja

original: kiṃ vācyo mahimā mahājalanidher yasyendravajrāhatas trasto bhūbhṛd amajjad ambunicaye kaulīlapotākṛtiḥ /
analyzed: kim vācyaḥ mahimā mahā jalanidheḥ yasya indra vajra āhataḥ trastaḥ bhūbhṛt amajjat ambu nicaye kaulīla pota ākṛtiḥ
translated: What can be said of the greatness of the great ocean, from which the frightened mountain, struck by Indra's thunderbolt, did not sink into the mass of water, but took the form of a small fish?

original: maināko 'pi gabhīranīraviluṭhan pāṭhīnapṛṣṭhocchalac chaivālāṅkurakoṭikoṭarakuṭīkuḍyāntare nirvṛtaḥ // / //
analyzed: mainākaḥ pi gabhīra nīra viluṭhan pāṭhīna pṛṣṭha ucchalat śaivāla aṅkura koṭi koṭara kuṭī kuḍya antare nirvṛtaḥ  /
translated: Even Maināka, rolling in the deep water, rising on the back of a large fish, found relief in the cave-like interior of a clump of seaweed.

original: vallaṇasya
analyzed: vallaṇasya
translated: Of Vallabha

original: tādṛksaptasamudramudritamahī bhūbhṛdbhir abhraṃkaṣais tāvadbhiḥ parivāritā pṛthupṛthudvīpaiḥ samantād iyam /
analyzed: tādṛś sapta samudra mudrita mahī bhūbhṛdbhiḥ abhraṃkaṣaiḥ tāvadbhiḥ parivāritā pṛthu pṛthu dvīpaiḥ samantāt iyam
translated: This earth, sealed with seven oceans, surrounded on all sides by those many vast continents, which are like the clouds that hold up the sky,

original: yasya sphāraphaṇāmaṇau nilayanāt tiryakkalaṅkākṛtiḥ śeṣaḥ so 'py agamad yadaṅgadapadaṃ tasmai namaḥ śambhave // / //
analyzed: yasya sphāra phaṇāmaṇau nilayanāt tiryak kalaṅka ākṛtiḥ śeṣaḥ saḥ pi agamat yat aṅgada padam tasmai namaḥ śambhave
translated: And on whose expansive hood-jewel, the serpent Shesha, who has the shape of a sideways-pointing Kalankamala flower, also became an ornament, to that Shambhu, I offer salutations.

original: vallaṇasya / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: vallaṇasya skmsauka
translated: Of Vallabha.

original: gāḍhagranthipraphulladgalavikalaphaṇāpīṭhaniryadviṣāgni jvālāniṣṭaptacandradravadamṛtarasaproṣitapretabhāvāḥ /
analyzed: gāḍha granthi praphullat gala vikala phaṇā pīṭha niryat viṣa agni jvālā niṣṭapta candra dravat amṛta rasa proṣita preta bhāvāḥ
translated: The fire of poison, bursting from the neck-pillow with its deep knot, the state of ghosts gone by the nectar-juice of the moon-liquor heated by the flames of that fire,

original: ujjṛmbhā babhrunetradyutim asakṛdasṛktṛṣṇayālokayantyaḥ pāntu tvāṃ nāganālagrathitaśavaśiraḥśreṇayo bhairavasya // /
analyzed: ujjṛmbhāḥ babhru netra dyutim asakṛt asṛj tṛṣṇayā ālokayantyaḥ pāntu tvām nāga nāla grathita śava śiraḥ śreṇayaḥ bhairavasya  /
translated: The yawns, repeatedly looking with thirst for blood at the light of the tawny eyes, may protect you, the rows of skulls strung on the naga-neck of Bhairava.

original: vallaṇasya Skmsa /u /ka / /
analyzed: vallaṇasya skmsauka
translated: Of Vallabha.

original: bhavabhūteḥ
analyzed: bhavabhūteḥ
translated: Of Bhavabhuti.

original: babhrubhrūśmaśrukeśaṃ śikharam iva girer lagnadāvāgnimālaṃ netraiḥ piṅgogratārais tribhir iva ravibhiś chidritaḥ kālameghaḥ /
analyzed: babhru bhrū śmaśru keśam śikharam iva gireḥ lagna dāva agni mālam netraiḥ piṅga ugra tāraiḥ tribhiḥ iva ravibhiḥ chidritaḥ kāla meghaḥ
translated: With tawny eyebrows, beard and hair, like the peak of a mountain, encircled by a garland of forest fires, pierced by three eyes like three suns, tawny and fierce-looking, like a dark rain cloud,

original: daṃṣṭrācandraprabhābhiḥ prakaṭitasubṛhattālupātālamūlaṃ śambhor vaktraṃ suvaktratritayabhayakaraṃ hantv adhaṃ dakṣiṇaṃ vaḥ // /
analyzed: daṃṣṭrā candra prabhābhiḥ prakaṭita su bṛhat tālu pātāla mūlam śambhoḥ vaktram su vaktra tritaya bhaya karam hantu adham dakṣiṇam vaḥ  /
translated: May the face of Shiva, the root of the netherworld revealed by the bright moonlight of his fangs, the lower right face, which terrifies the three good faces, destroy your sins.

original: rakṣovibhīṣaṇasya 🔽uddāmadantarucipallavitārdhacandra jyotsnānipītatimiraprakarāvarodhaḥ /
analyzed: rakṣaḥ vibhīṣaṇasya  uddāma danta ruci pallavita ardhacandra jyotsnā nipīta timira prakara avarodhaḥ
translated: Of Vibhishana, the demon🔽The mass of darkness, which was drunk up by the moonlight spreading from the half-moons of the bright fangs,

original: śreyāṃsi vo diśatu tāṇḍavitasya śambhor ambhodharāvalighanadhvanir aṭṭahāsaḥ // / //
analyzed: śreyāṃsi vaḥ diśatu tāṇḍavitasya śambhoḥ ambhodhara āvali ghana dhvaniḥ aṭṭahāsaḥ
translated: May the loud laughter of Shiva, who dances, and whose sound is like a series of clouds, bestow blessings upon you.

original: saṅghamitrasya / Skmsa /u /ka / 🔽tvaṅgadgaṅgam udañcadinduśakalaṃ bhraśyatkapālāvali kroḍabhrāmyadamandamārutacayasphārībhavadbhāṅkṛti /
analyzed: saṅgha mitrasya skmsauka  tu aṅgat gaṅgam udañcat indu śakalam bhraśyat kapāla āvali kroḍa bhrāmyat amanda māruta caya sphārībhavat bhāṅkṛti
translated: Of Sanghamitra. SKMs.U.Ka.🔽With the Ganges flowing on it, the crescent moon rising, a row of falling skulls, and the radiance spreading from the strong wind whirling in its lap,

original: pāyād vo ghanatāṇḍavavyatikaraprāgbhārakhedaskhalad bhogīndraślathapiṅgalotkaṭajaṭājūṭaṃ śiro dhūrjaṭeḥ // / //
analyzed: pāyāt vaḥ ghana tāṇḍava vyatikara prāgbhāra kheda skhalat bhogi indra ślatha piṅgala utkaṭa jaṭā jūṭam śiraḥ dhūrjaṭeḥ  /
translated: May Shiva's head, with the matted hair falling loosely from the heavy weight of the dance, bestow protection upon you.

original: Skmsa /u /ka / / vīryamitrasya
analyzed: vīrya mitrasya
translated: Of Viryamitra. SKMs.U.Ka.

original: nakhadarpaṇasaṃkrānta pratimādaśakānvitaḥ /
analyzed: nakha darpaṇa saṃkrānta pratimā daśaka anvitaḥ
translated: May Shiva, who is accompanied by ten images reflected in the mirror of his nails,

original: gaurīpādānataḥ śambhur jayatv ekādaśaḥ svayam // / //
analyzed: gaurī pādānataḥ śambhuḥ jayatu ekādaśaḥ svayam
translated: and who bows at the feet of Gauri, be victorious in his eleventh form.

original: cūḍāpīḍakapālasaṃkulapatanmandākinīvārayo vidyutprāyalalāṭalocanapuṭajyotirvimiśratviṣaḥ /
analyzed: cūḍāpīḍa kapāla saṃkula patat mandākinī vārayaḥ vidyut prāya lalāṭa locana puṭa jyotiḥ vimiśra tviṣaḥ
translated: May the matted locks of the Lord of spirits, girt with a zone of the serpent Shesha, and whose lustre is mingled with the light of the eyes on the forehead, which are mostly like lightning, and which are the abode of the Mandakini river flowing with the skulls of the Chodas, protect you.

original: pāntu tvām akaṭhoraketakaśikhāsaṃdigdhamugdhendavo bhūteśasya bhugaṅgavallivalayasraṅnaddhajūṭā jaṭāḥ // / //
analyzed: pāntu tvām a kaṭhora ketaka śikhā saṃdigdha mugdha indavaḥ bhūteśasya bhuj aṅga valli valaya sraj naddha jūṭāḥ jaṭāḥ  /
translated: Whose matted locks resemble the crescent moon on Shiva's head, doubtful of being a tender ketaki flower, and whose lustre is mixed with the light of the eyes on the forehead, which are mostly like lightning, and which are the abode of the Mandakini river flowing with the skulls of the Chodas, protect you.

original: bhavabhūteḥ mālavikāgnimā /a /mitram i / /
analyzed: bhavabhūteḥ
translated: Of Bhavabhuti, in the Malavikagnimitra.

original: sa jayati gāṅgajalaughaḥ śambhor uttuṅgamauliviniviṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: sa jayati gāṅga jala oghaḥ śambhoḥ uttuṅga mauli viniviṣṭaḥ
translated: Victorious is the stream of Ganga water, placed on Shiva's lofty crown,

original: majjati punar unmajjati candrakalā yatra śapharīva // / //🔽sa vaḥ pāyād indur navavisalatākoṭikuṭilaḥ smarārer yo mūrdhni jvalanakapiśe bhāti nihitaḥ /
analyzed: majjati punar unmajjati candra kalā yatra śapharī iva  sa vaḥ pāyāt induḥ nava visa latā koṭi kuṭilaḥ smarāreḥ yaḥ mūrdhni jvalana kapiśe bhāti nihitaḥ
translated: Where the digit of the moon, like a carp, sinks and rises again.🔽May that moon, crooked like a fresh creeper, protect you, which, placed on the head of the enemy of love, shines like a sprout, white like crystal,

original: sravanmandākinyāḥ pratidivasasiktena payasā kapālenonmuktaḥ sphaṭikadhavalenāṅkura iva // / //
analyzed: sravat mandākinyāḥ prati divasa siktena payasā kapālena unmuktaḥ sphaṭika dhavalena aṅkuraḥ iva  /
translated: Released from the skull, moistened daily with the water of the flowing Mandakini.

original: kasyacit / Skmsa /u /ka / /
analyzed: kasyacid
translated: Of someone.

original: rājaśekharasya
analyzed: rājaśekharasya
translated: Of Rajasekhara.

original: cyutām indor lekhāṃ ratikalahabhagnaṃ ca valayaṃ dvayaṃ cakrīkṛtya prahasitamukhī śailatanayā /
analyzed: cyutām indoḥ lekhām rati kalaha bhagnam ca valayam dvayam cakrīkṛtya prahasita mukhī śailatanayā
translated: The daughter of the mountain, with a smiling face, having made a pair of bracelets out of the digit of the moon fallen from Shiva's head and the bracelet broken in the quarrel of love,

original: avocad yaṃ paśyedty avatu sa śivaḥ sā ca girijā sa ca krīḍācandro daśanakiraṇāpūritakalaḥ // / //
analyzed: avocat yam paśyet iti avatu sa śivaḥ sā ca girijā sa ca krīḍā candraḥ daśana kiraṇa āpūrita kalaḥ  /
translated: May that Shiva protect you, whom Parvati said, May he protect you, whom you see, and may she protect you, who sees him, and may that moon of play, filled with the rays of her teeth, protect you all.

original: vararuceḥ / Skmsa /u /ka / /
analyzed: vararuceḥ skmsauka
translated: Of Vararuchi.🔽Of Susruta.

original: Svsu /ā / / Spdśā /pa / 🔽namas tuṅgaśiraś cumbi candracāmaracārave /
analyzed: sv su ā  namaḥ tuṅga śiraḥ cumbi candra cāmara cārave
translated: Of Spandananda.

original: trailokyanagarārambha mūlastambhāya śambhave // / //
analyzed: trailokya nagara ārambha mūla stambhāya śambhave
translated: Salutations to Shambhu, the original pillar of the foundation of the city of the three worlds, whose long-flowing hair is kissed by the moon-flapping fan.🔽Of someone.

original: kasyacit / Skmsa /u /ka / / bāṇasya
analyzed: kasyacid skmsauka bāṇasya
translated: Of Bana.

original: kṣipto hastāvalagnaḥ prasabham abhihato 'py ādadāno 'ṃśukāntaṃ gṛhṇan keśeṣv apāstaś caraṇanipatito nekṣitaḥ saṃbhrameṇa /
analyzed: kṣiptaḥ hasta avalagnaḥ prasabham abhihataḥ pi ādadānaḥ ṃśuka antam gṛhṇan keśeṣu apāstaḥ caraṇa nipatitaḥ na īkṣitaḥ saṃbhrameṇa
translated: Though thrown down, held by the hand, violently struck, still holding the hem of her garment, seized by the hair, pushed away, fallen at her feet, not looked at in confusion,

original: āliṅgan yo 'vadhūtas tripurayuvatibhiḥ sāśrunetrotpalābhiḥ kāmīvārdrāparādhaḥ sa dahatu duritaṃ śāmbhavo vaḥ śarāgniḥ // /
analyzed: āliṅgan yaḥ vadhūtaḥ tripura yuvatibhiḥ sa aśru netra utpalābhiḥ kāmī iva ārdra aparādhaḥ sa dahatu duritam śāmbhavaḥ vaḥ śara agniḥ  /
translated: embraced, rejected by the tearful blue-lotus-eyed young women of Tripura, may Shiva's fire of passion, like a lover with a wet offense, burn away your sins.

original: Amaru / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: amaru
translated: Of Amaru.

original: saṃdhyātāṇḍavaḍambaravyasanino bhīmasya caṇḍabhrami vyānṛtyadbhujadaṇḍamaṇḍalabhuvo jhañjhānilāḥ pāntu vaḥ /
analyzed: saṃdhyā tāṇḍava ḍambara vyasaninaḥ bhīmasya caṇḍa bhrami vyānṛtyat bhuja daṇḍa maṇḍala bhuvaḥ jhañjhā anilāḥ pāntu vaḥ
translated: May the winds, which are the circular regions of the terrible and whirling arms of Shiva, who is addicted to the evening Tandava dance, protect you all.

original: yeṣām ucchalatāṃ javena jhagiti vyūheṣu bhūmībhṛtām uḍḍīneṣu viḍaujasā punar asau dambholir ālokitaḥ // / //
analyzed: yeṣām ucchalatām javena vyūheṣu bhūmībhṛtām uḍḍīneṣu viḍaujasā punar asau dambholiḥ ālokitaḥ  /
translated: Whose rising with speed, suddenly in the arrays of the kings, when they were flying, this thunderbolt was seen again.

original: Skmsa /u /ka / / Smvsū /mu / /🔽keśeṣu prākpradīpas tvaci vikaṭacaṭatkārasāro 'timātraṃ māṃse mandāyamānaḥ kṣaradasṛji sṛjann asthiṣu ṣṭhātkṛtāni /
analyzed: skmsauka  keśeṣu prāc pradīpaḥ tvaci timātram māṃse mandāyamānaḥ kṣarat asṛji sṛjan asthiṣu
translated: SkmSu.u.k. SmvSu.mu.🔽In the hair, the lamp was first, in the skin, the essence of the loud crackling sound was excessive, in the flesh, it was slowly burning, in the flowing blood, it was creating hissing sounds in the bones.

original: majjaprāye 'ṅgabhāge jhagiti ratipater jājvalan projjvalaśrīr aśreyo vyasyatād vastrinayananayanopāntavānto hutāśaḥ // / 🔽pāyāt pārvaṇasāndhyatāṇḍavavidhau yasyollasatkānano hemādriḥ karaṇāṅgahāravalanaiḥ sārdhendur āndolitaḥ /🔽dhatte 'tyadbhutavismayena dharayā dhūtasya kāntatviṣo lolatkuntalakuṇḍalasya śirasaḥ śobhāṃ sa vo dhūrjaṭiḥ // / //
analyzed: majja prāye ṅga bhāge ratipateḥ jājvalan projjvala śrīḥ aśreyaḥ vyasyatāt vaḥ tri nayana nayana upānta vāntaḥ hutāśaḥ  / pāyāt pārvaṇa sāndhya tāṇḍava vidhau yasya ullasat kānanaḥ hemādriḥ karaṇa aṅgahāra valanaiḥ sārdha induḥ āndolitaḥ  dhatte ti adbhuta vismayena dharayā dhūtasya kānta tviṣaḥ lolat kuntala kuṇḍalasya śirasaḥ śobhām sa vaḥ dhūrjaṭiḥ
translated: In the part of the body full of marrow, the fire of love, with its splendor blazing, suddenly spread. May that fire, which ends in the eyes of the three-eyed one, remove your misfortune.🔽May he protect you, in whose evening twilight dance of the full moon, the golden mountain shines forth with the forest, and the crescent moon is swayed by the movements of the limbs and the gestures.🔽May that Shiva, whose head, with its moving locks and earrings, has the splendor of a beloved's face, with the earth bearing it in great wonder, protect you.

original: kapāle gambhīraḥ kuhariṇi jaṭāsandhiṣu kṛśaḥ samuttālaś cūḍābhujagaphaṇaratnavyatikare /
analyzed: kapāle gambhīraḥ kuhariṇi jaṭā sandhiṣu kṛśaḥ sa muttālaḥ cūḍā bhujaga phaṇa ratna vyatikare
translated: Deep in the skull, thin in the joints of the matted hair, and very active in the clash of the jewels on the hoods of the snakes in the topknot,

original: mṛdur lekhākoṇe rayavaśavilolasya śaśinaḥ punīyād dīrghaṃ svo haraśirasi gaṅgākalakalaḥ // / //
analyzed: mṛduḥ lekhā koṇe raya vaśa vilolasya śaśinaḥ punīyāt dīrgham svaḥ hara śirasi gaṅgā kalakalaḥ
translated: May the long-drawn sound of the Ganges on Shiva's head purify the world, the soft sound of the moon wavering in the rays.

original: Skmsa /u /ka / / yogeśvarasya
analyzed: yogeśvarasya
translated: Of Yogeshvara

original: śāntyai vo 'stu kapāladāma jagatāṃ patur yadīyāṃ lipiṃ kvāpi kvāpi gaṇāḥ paṭhanti padaśo nātiprasiddhākṣaram /
analyzed: śāntyai vaḥ stu kapāla dāma jagatām patuḥ yadīyām lipim kvāpi kvāpi gaṇāḥ paṭhanti padaśas na ati prasiddha akṣaram
translated: May the garland of skulls of the world be for your peace, which the groups of Gaṇas recite in parts here and there, with not very well-known letters.

original: viśvaṃ srakṣyati rakṣati kṣitim apām īśiṣyate śiṣyate nāgau rāgiṣu raṃsyate syati jagan nirvekṣyati dyām iti // / //
analyzed: viśvam srakṣyati rakṣati kṣitim apām īśiṣyate śiṣyate nāgau rāgiṣu raṃsyate syati jagat nirvekṣyati dyām iti  /
translated: It will create the universe, it will protect the earth, it will be the lord of the waters, it will be studied, the two serpents will play among the passionate ones, it will destroy the world, it will look at the sky...

original: bhojadevasya / Skmsa /u /ka / 🔽jvālevordhvavisarpiṇī pariṇatasyāntas tapas tejaso gaṅgātuṅgataraṅgasarpavasatir valmīkalakṣmīr iva /
analyzed: bhojadevasya  jvālā iva ūrdhva visarpiṇī pariṇatasya antar tapaḥ tejasaḥ gaṅgā tuṅga taraṅga sarpa vasatiḥ valmīka lakṣmīḥ iva
translated: Of Bhoja Deva.🔽Like a flame rising upwards, the glory of the anthill, the abode of the waves of the Ganges, like the prosperity of the anthill, from the perfected inner heat of austerity.

original: saṃdhyevārdramṛṇālakomalatanor indoḥ sahasthāyinī pāyād vas taruṇāruṇāṃśukapiśā śambhor jaṭāsaṃhatiḥ // / //
analyzed: saṃdhyā iva ārdra mṛṇāla komala tanoḥ indoḥ saha sthāyinī pāyāt vaḥ taruṇa aruṇa aṃśu kapiśā śambhoḥ jaṭā saṃhatiḥ  /
translated: May Shiva's matted hair, tawny like the young morning sunlight, protect you, abiding with the moon, whose body is tender like a wet lotus stalk, like the evening twilight.

original: Skmsa /u /ka / / ravināgasya
analyzed: ravi nāgasya
translated: Of Ravinaga.

original: maulau vegād udañcaty api caraṇabharanyañcadurvītalatvād akṣuṇṇasvargalokasthitimuditasuraśreṣṭhagoṣṭhīstutāya /
analyzed: maulau vegāt udañcati api caraṇa bhara nyañcat urvī tala tvāt a kṣuṇṇa svarga loka sthiti mudita sura śreṣṭha goṣṭhī stutāya
translated: To the one praised by the assembly of the best gods delighted by the unshaken state in the heavenly world due to the heaviness of the feet rising up quickly on the head,

original: saṃtrāsān niḥsarantyāpy aviratavisaraddakṣiṇārdhānubandhād atyaktāyādriputryā tirpuraharajagatkleśahantre namas te // /
analyzed: saṃtrāsāt niḥsarantyā api avirata visarat dakṣiṇa ardha anubandhāt a tyaktāya adri putryā tirpura hara jagat kleśa hantre namaḥ te  /
translated: To the one who has not abandoned the daughter of the mountain, who is following the southern half that is constantly spreading out even while escaping from fear, I offer salutations to you, the remover of the world's suffering, the destroyer of the lord of the demons.

original: Skmsa /u /ka / / bāṇasya
analyzed: bāṇasya
translated: Skms.u.k.

original: paryaṅkāśleṣabandhadviguṇitabhujagagranthisaṃvītajānor antaḥprāṇāvarodhād uparatasakaladhyānaruddhendriyasya /
analyzed: paryaṅka āśleṣa bandha dvi guṇita bhujaga granthi saṃvīta jānoḥ antar prāṇa avarodhāt uparata sakala dhyāna ruddha indriyasya
translated: Of the one whose thighs are tightly bound by the coils of a serpent doubled from the embrace of the couch, whose senses are restrained by the cessation of all meditation from the obstruction of the breath within,

original: ātmany ātmānam eva vyapagatakaraṇaṃ paśyatas tattvadṛṣṭyā śambhor vaḥ pātu śūnyakṣaṇaghaṭitalayabrahmalagnaḥ samādhiḥ // /
analyzed: ātmani ātmānam eva vyapagata karaṇam paśyataḥ tattva dṛṣṭyā śambhoḥ vaḥ pātu śūnya kṣaṇa ghaṭita laya brahma lagnaḥ samādhiḥ
translated: Of the one who sees the self alone in the self, with the senses withdrawn, by seeing the truth, may Shiva's samadhi, which is fixed in the Brahman of the dissolution formed by the void moment, protect you all.

original: pāyād vārendumauler anavaratabhujāvṛttivātormivega bhrāmyadrudrārkatārāgaṇaracitamahālātacakrasya lāsyam /
analyzed: pāyāt vāra indu mauleḥ anavarata bhuja āvṛtti vāta ūrmi vega bhrāmyat rudra arka tārā gaṇa racita mahā lāta cakrasya lāsyam
translated: May the dance of the great wheel of fire, formed by the multitude of Rudras, suns, and stars, whirling with the speed of the wind from the constant movement of the arms of the one with the moon on his forehead, protect you.

original: nyañcadbhūtsarpadagniskhaladakhilagiritvaṅgaduttālamauli sphūrjaccandrāṃśuniryannayanarucirasajjāhnavīnirjharaḥ vaḥ // /
analyzed: nyañcat bhūt sarpat agni skhalat akhila giri tvaṅgat uttāla mauli sphūrjat candra aṃśu niryat nayana ruci rasat jāhnavī nirjharaḥ vaḥ
translated: The serpents hanging down, the fire stumbling on all the moving mountain peaks, the water of the Ganges flowing forth from his eye, which is charming with the moonbeams issuing forth, may protect you all.

original: mātar jīva kim etad añjalipuṭe tātena gopāyitaṃ vatsa svāduphalaṃ prayacchati na me gatvā gṛhāṇa svayam /
analyzed: mātar jīva kim etat añjali puṭe tātena gopāyitam vatsa svādu phalam prayacchati na me gatvā gṛhāṇa svayam
translated: Mother, what is this that father is hiding in his cupped hands? He will not give me the sweet fruit, child. Go and take it yourself.

original: mātraivaṃ prahite guhe vighaṭayaty ākṛṣya saṃdhyāñjaliṃ śambhor bhagnasamādhiruddharabhaso hāsyodgamaḥ pātu vaḥ // / //
analyzed: mātrā evam prahite guhe vighaṭayati ākṛṣya saṃdhyā añjalim śambhoḥ bhagna samādhi ruddha rabhasaḥ hāsya udgamaḥ pātu vaḥ  /
translated: When Guha is thus sent by his mother, he breaks the evening offering by pulling it apart. May the laughter of Shiva, who has interrupted his meditation, protect you all.

original: yogeśvarasya / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: yogeśvarasya
translated: Of the Lord of Yoga.

original: evaṃ sthāpaya subhru bāhulatikām evaṃ kuru sthānakaṃ nātyuccair nama kuñcitāgracaraṇaṃ māṃ paśya tāvat kṣaṇam /
analyzed: evam sthāpaya subhru bāhu latikām evam kuru sthānakam na ati uccais nama kuñcita agra caraṇam mām paśya tāvat kṣaṇam
translated: Thus, O you with beautiful eyebrows, hold your arms like this, make your posture like this, do not bend your feet too high, look at me for a moment.

original: gaurīṃ nartayataḥ svavaktramurajenāmbhodharadhvāninā śambhor vaḥ sukhayantu lambhitalayacchedāhatās tālikāḥ // / //
analyzed: gaurīm nartayataḥ sva vaktra murajena ambhodhara dhvāninā śambhoḥ vaḥ sukhayantu lambhita laya cheda āhatāḥ tālikāḥ  /
translated: May the cymbals struck with a cut-off beat obtained by the rhythm of Shiva's dancing with his own drum, the sound of which is like the rumbling of clouds, bring you joy.

original: tasyaiva / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: tasya eva
translated: Of the same.

original: saṃvyānāṃśukapallaveṣu taralaṃ veṇīguṇeṣu sthiraṃ mandaṃ kañcukasandhiṣu stanataṭotsaṅgeṣu dīptārciṣam /
analyzed: saṃvyāna aṃśuka pallaveṣu taralam veṇī guṇeṣu sthiram mandam kañcuka sandhiṣu stana taṭa utsaṅgeṣu dīpta arciṣam
translated: Moving playfully on the hems of the silken garments, steady on the braids of hair, slow at the seams of the bodice, with bright flames on the tops of the breasts,

original: ālokya tripurāvarodhanavadhūvargasya dhūmadhvajaṃ hastasrastaśarāsano vijayate devo dayārdrekṣaṇaḥ // / //
analyzed: ālokya tripura avarodha na vadhū vargasya dhūmadhvajam hasta srasta śarāsanaḥ vijayate devaḥ dayā ārdra īkṣaṇaḥ
translated: Seeing the smoke-banner of the group of wives of Tripura's women, the god, with his eyes wet with compassion, is victorious, with his bow and arrows fallen from his hand.

original: Skmsa /u /ka / 🔽jaṭāgulmotsaṅgaṃ praviśati śaśī bhasmagahanaṃ phaṇīndro 'pi skandhād avatarati līlāñcitaphaṇaḥ /
analyzed: skmsauka  jaṭā gulma utsaṅgam praviśati śaśī bhasma gahanam phaṇi indraḥ pi skandhāt avatarati līlā āñcita phaṇaḥ
translated: Skms.u.k.🔽The moon enters the thicket of matted hair, and the king of serpents descends from his shoulder with his hood playfully coiled.

original: vṛṣaḥ śāṭhyaṃ kṛtvā vilikhati khurāgreṇa nayanaṃ yadā śambhuś cumbaty acaladuhitur vaktrakamalam // / //
analyzed: vṛṣaḥ śāṭhyam kṛtvā vilikhati khura agreṇa nayanam yadā śambhuḥ cumbati acala duhituḥ vaktra kamalam
translated: When the bull scratches his eye with the tip of his horn, acting deceitfully, then Shiva kisses the lotus face of his daughter of the mountains.

original: rājaśekharasya
analyzed: rājaśekharasya
translated: Of Rajasekhara

original: nānāvegaviniḥsṛtatripathagāvāripravāhākulaḥ śīghrabhrāntivaśāllalāṭanayanākālātapād bhīṣaṇaḥ /
analyzed: nānā vega viniḥsṛta tripathagā vāri pravāha ākulaḥ śīghra bhrānti vaśāt lalāṭa nayana akāla ātapāt bhīṣaṇaḥ
translated: Agitated by the currents of the three-flowing river flowing in various directions, terrifying due to the quick glances of the eyes of Shiva's consort,

original: muṇḍālīkuharaprasarpadanilāsphālapramuktadhvaniḥ prāvṛṭkāla ivoditaḥ śivaśiromeghaḥ śivāyāstu vaḥ // / //
analyzed: muṇḍālī kuhara prasarpat anila āsphāla pramukta dhvaniḥ prāvṛṣ kāle iva uditaḥ śiva śiraḥ meghaḥ śivāya astu vaḥ  /
translated: With the sound released by the wind blowing through the hollows of the skulls, may the cloud on Shiva's head, arisen like the rainy season, bring welfare to you all.

original: kasyacit
analyzed: kasyacid
translated: Of someone

original: sa pātu viśvam adyāpi yasya mūrdhni navaḥ śaśī /
analyzed: sa pātu viśvam adyā api yasya mūrdhni navaḥ śaśī
translated: May he protect the universe even today, on whose head is the fresh moon,

original: gaurīmukhatiraskāra lajjayeva na vardhate // / //
analyzed: gaurī mukha tiraskāra lajjayā iva na vardhate  /
translated: As if ashamed, it does not increase, as if to avoid being surpassed by the face of Gauri.

original: dharmapālasya 🔽digvāsā iti satrapaṃ manasijadveṣīti mugdhasmitaṃ sāścaryaṃ viṣamekṣaṇo 'yam iti ca trastaṃ kapālīti ca /
analyzed: dharmapālasya  digvāsāḥ iti sa trapam manasija dveṣī iti mugdha smitam sa āścaryam viṣama īkṣaṇaḥ yam iti ca trastam kapālī iti ca
translated: [of Dharmapala]🔽Naked, with shame, hating Cupid, with a sweet smile, with wonder, with fearful eyes, with a skull-bowl,

original: maulisvīkṛtajāhnavīka iti ca prāptābhyasūyaṃ haraḥ pārvatyā sabhayaṃ bhujaṅgavalayīty ālokitaḥ pātu vaḥ // / //
analyzed: mauli svīkṛta jāhnavīkaḥ iti ca prāpta abhyasūyam haraḥ pārvatyā sa bhayam bhujaṅga valayī iti ālokitaḥ pātu vaḥ  /
translated: With the Ganges accepted on his head, with jealousy, Shiva is looked at with fear by Parvati, with a garland of snakes. May he protect you all.

original: vinayadevasya
analyzed: vinayadevasya
translated: [of Vinayadeva]

original: phaṇini śikhigrahakupite śikhini ca taddehavalayitākulite /
analyzed: phaṇini śikhi graha kupite śikhini ca tad deha valayita ākulite
translated: When the serpent is angry at the peacock's seizure, and the peacock is agitated by encircling his body,

original: avatād vo haraguhayor ubhayaparitrāṇakātaratā // / //
analyzed: avatāt vaḥ hara guhayoḥ ubhaya paritrāṇa kātara tā
translated: May the fear of both being protected by Hara and Guha protect you all.

original: jātārdhavardhanasya
analyzed: jāta ardha vardhanasya
translated: [of Jataradhavardhana]

original: sindūraśrīr lalāṭe kanakarasamayaḥ karṇapāśāvataṃso vaktre tāmbūlarāgaḥ pṛthukucakalase kuṅkumasyānulepaḥ /
analyzed: sindūra śrīḥ lalāṭe kanaka rasa mayaḥ karṇa pāśa avataṃsaḥ vaktre tāmbūla rāgaḥ pṛthu kuca kalase kuṅkumasya anulepaḥ
translated: The vermilion beauty on the forehead, the earring made of gold liquid, the betel nut color on the face, the saffron ointment on the plump breasts,

original: daityādhīśāṅganānāṃ jaghanaparisare lākṣikakṣaumalakṣmīr aśreyāṃsi kṣiṇotu tripuraharaśarodgārajanmānalo vaḥ // / //
analyzed: daitya adhīśa aṅganānām jaghana parisare lākṣika kṣauma lakṣmīḥ aśreyāṃsi kṣiṇotu tripura hara śara udgāra janma analaḥ vaḥ  /
translated: The beauty of the silken garment with lac on the hips of the wives of the demon kings - may the fire born from the discharge of Shiva's arrow destroy your inauspiciousness.

original: maṅgalasya / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: maṅgalasya skmsauka
translated: [of Mangala]

original: pāyād vaḥ surajāhnavījalarayabhrāmyajjaṭāmaṇḍalī vegavyākulanāganāyakaphaṇāphūtkāravātocchalam /
analyzed: pāyāt vaḥ sura jāhnavī jala raya bhrāmyat jaṭā maṇḍalī vega vyākula nāga nāyaka phaṇā phūtkāra vāta ucchalam
translated: May Shiva protect you, whose matted locks are tossed by the waves of the Ganges, whose body is shaken by the hissing of the hoods of the agitated serpent king,

original: saptāmbhonidhijanmacaṇḍalaharīmajjannabhomaṇḍala trāsatrastasurāṅganākalakalavrīḍāvilakṣo haraḥ // / //
translated: whose face is ashamed by the loud cries of the terrified celestial women at the sinking of the sky-mandala in the churning of the seven oceans.

original: karkarājasya Skmsa /u /ka / /
analyzed: karkarājasya skmsauka
translated: Of Karkkaraja, SKMSu.U.Ka.

original: brahmahareḥ🔽purastād ānamratridaśapatigārutmatamaṇer vataṃsatrāsārter apasarati mauñjīphaṇipatau /
analyzed: brahmahareḥ  purastāt ānamra tridaśa pati gārutmata maṇeḥ vataṃsa trāsa ārteḥ apasarati mauñjī phaṇi patau
translated: Of Brahma-Hara,🔽In front of the crest-jewel of the lord of the gods, Garuda, frightened by the earrings, the Mouji serpent-banner flees.

original: purāriḥ saṃvṛṇvan vigaladupasaṃvyānam ajine punītād vaḥ smerakṣitidharasutāpāṅgaviṣayaḥ // / //
analyzed: purāriḥ saṃvṛṇvan vigalat upasaṃvyānam ajine punītāt vaḥ smera kṣitidhara suta apāṅga viṣayaḥ
translated: May Shiva, who covers himself with a deer-skin, his upper garment fallen off, and whose eyes are on his forehead, purify you, his eyes directed towards the side-glances of the smiling daughter of the earth.

original: dharmāśokasya
analyzed: dharmāśokasya
translated: Of Dharmashoka,

original: jīrṇe 'py utkaṭakālakūṭakavale dagdhe haṭhān manmathe nīte bhāsurabhālanetratanutāṃ kalpāntadāvānale /
analyzed: jīrṇe pi utkaṭa kālakūṭa kavale dagdhe haṭhāt manmathe nīte bhāsura bhāla netra tanu tām kalpa anta dāva anale
translated: Even when the old, powerful poison was swallowed, when Kama was forcibly burnt in the fire of the final destruction,

original: yaḥ śaktyā samalaṃkṛto 'pi śaśinaṃ śrīśailajāṃ svardhunīṃ dhatte kautukarājanītinipuṇaḥ pāyāt sa vaḥ śaṅkaraḥ // / //
analyzed: yaḥ śaktyā samalaṃkṛtaḥ u pi śaśinam śrīśailajām svardhunīm dhatte kautuka rāja nīti nipuṇaḥ pāyāt sa vaḥ śaṅkaraḥ  /
translated: May that Shiva, adorned with Shakti, who holds the moon, the river rising from the mountain of Shri, skilled in the policy of the king of wonders, protect you all.

original: kavirājasya
analyzed: kavirājasya
translated: Of Kaviraja,

original: iti śrīmaheśvaravrajyā ////
analyzed: iti śrī maheśvaravrajyā
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the great Shiva.

original: tatas tadvargavrajyā
analyzed: tatas tad varga vrajyā
translated: Then, the series of verses on that group

original: devī sūnum asūta nṛtyata gaṇāḥ kiṃ tiṣṭhatety udbhuje harṣād bhṛṅgariṭāvayācitagirā cāmuṇḍayāliṅgite /
analyzed: devī sūnum asūta nṛtyata gaṇāḥ kim tiṣṭhata iti udbhuje harṣāt bhṛṅgariṭa avayācita girā cāmuṇḍayā āliṅgite
translated: The goddess gave birth to a son, the ganas raised their arms in joy, saying, Why stand still? embraced by Amunḍā, whose voice was requested by Bhṛṅgiriṭi in delight,

original: avyād vo hatadundubhisvanaghanadhvānātiriktas tayor anyonyapracalāsthitpañjararaṇatkaṅkālajanmā ravaḥ // / //
analyzed: avyāt vaḥ hata dundubhi svana ghana dhvāna atiriktaḥ tayoḥ anyonya pracala āsthit pañjara raṇat kaṅkāla janmā ravaḥ
translated: May their sound, born from the rattling of the cage of their mutually trembling bodies, which exceeds the thick sound of the beaten kettledrums, protect you all.

original: yogeśvarasya /
analyzed: yogeśvarasya
translated: Of Yogīśvara.

original: Skmsa /u /ka / / Smvsū /mu / /🔽rakṣatu vaḥ stanayugalaṃ harikarikumbhānukāri giriguhituḥ /
analyzed: skmsauka  rakṣatu vaḥ stana yugalam hari kari kumbha anukāri giri guhituḥ
translated: SKMSu.U.Ka.🔽May the pair of breasts of the daughter of the mountain, which resemble the cheeks of Hari's elephant, protect you all.

original: śaṅkaradṛḍhakaṇṭhagrahapīḍanabhasmāṅgarāgavicchuritam // / //
analyzed: śaṅkara dṛḍha kaṇṭhagraha pīḍana bhasma aṅga rāga vicchuritam
translated: Which are smeared with the ash from the tight embrace of Śaṅkara's neck.

original: dakṣasya🔽sāvaṣṭambhaniśumbhasaṃbhramanamadbhūgolaniṣpīḍana nyañcatkarparakūrmakampavicaṭadbrahmāṇḍakhaṇḍasthiti /
analyzed: dakṣasya
translated: Of Dakṣa.🔽The churning of the trembling earth due to the suppression of Niśumbha and Śuṃbha, the shaking of the tortoise shell as the earth is pressed down, and the scattered pieces of the Brahmāṇḍa remaining,

original: pātālapratimallagallavivaraprakṣiptasaptārṇavaṃ vande nanditanīlakaṇṭhapariṣadvyaktarddhi vaḥ krīḍitam // / //
translated: The seven oceans thrown into the gaping mouth of Pātāla, I praise your play, which manifests the prosperity of the delighted assembly of Nīlakaṇṭhas.

original: kasyacit
analyzed: kasyacid
translated: Of someone.

original: bho bho dikpatayaḥ prayāta parataḥ khaṃ muñcatāmbhomucaḥ pātālaṃ vraja medini praviśata kṣoṇītalaṃ kṣmābhṛtaḥ /
analyzed: bho bho dikpatayaḥ prayāta paratas kham muñcata ambhomucaḥ pātālam vraja medini praviśata kṣoṇī talam kṣmābhṛtaḥ
translated: O lords of the directions, go away! Let the clouds release rain elsewhere. O earth, go to the nether world. O mountains, enter the ground.

original: brahmann unnaya dūram ātmasadanaṃ devasya me nṛtyataḥ śambhoḥ saṃkaṭam etad ity avatu vaḥ protsāraṇā nandinaḥ // / //
analyzed: brahman unnaya dūram ātma sadanam devasya me nṛtyataḥ śambhoḥ saṃkaṭam etat iti avatu vaḥ protsāraṇā nandinaḥ  /
translated: O Brahma, take your abode far away. O Nandi, clear the way, saying This is a difficult situation for the dancing Lord Shiva. May this protection of Nandi be for your welfare.🔽SKMs_1.1: Yogesvara's.

original: Skmsa /u /ka / / yogeśvarasya / Smvsū /mu / /
analyzed: yogeśvarasya smvsūmu
translated: SKMs_1.2: Smvsu.mu.

original: svedas te katham īdṛśaḥ priyatame tvannetravahner vibho kasmāt kampitam etad induvadane bhogīndrabhīter bhava /
analyzed: svedaḥ te katham īdṛśaḥ priyatame tvad netra vahneḥ vibho kasmāt kampitam etat indu vadane bhogi indra bhīteḥ bhava
translated: O beloved, how is this sweat of yours? O Lord, from the fire of your eyes. Why is this trembling, O moon-faced one? It is from the fear of the king of serpents.

original: romāñcaḥ katham eṣa devi bhagavan gaṅgāmbhasāṃ śīkarar itthaṃ bhartari bhāvagopanaparā gaurī ciraṃ pātu vaḥ // / //
analyzed: romāñcaḥ katham eṣa devi bhagavan gaṅgā ambhasām śīkaraḥ ittham bhartari bhāva gopana parā gaurī ciram pātu vaḥ  /
translated: O Goddess, how is this horripilation? It is from the spray of the waters of the Ganges. Thus, may Gauri, skilled in concealing her feelings towards her husband, always protect you.

original: Skmsa /u /ka / / lakṣmīdharasya
analyzed: lakṣmīdharasya
translated: SKMs_1.3: Lakshmidhara's.

original: ārdrāṃ kaṇṭhe mukhābjasrajam avanamayaty ambikā jānulambāṃ sthāne kṛtvendulekhāṃ nibiḍayati jaṭāḥ pannagendreṇa nandī /
analyzed: ārdrām kaṇṭhe mukha abja srajam avanamayati ambikā jānu lambām sthāne kṛtvā indu lekhām nibiḍayati jaṭāḥ pannaga indreṇa nandī
translated: Ambika bends down the garland of lotus faces hanging down to her knees, places the moon's rays in their proper place, and binds her matted locks with the king of serpents. Nandi,

original: kālaḥ kṛttiṃ nibadhnāty upanayati kare kālarātriḥ kapālaṃ śambhor nṛtyāvatāre pariṣad iti pṛthag vyāpṛtā vaḥ punātu // / //
analyzed: kālaḥ kṛttim nibadhnāti upanayati kare kālarātriḥ kapālam śambhoḥ nṛtyāvatāre pariṣad iti pṛthak vyāpṛtāḥ vaḥ punātu  /
translated: May the assembly of the attendants of Lord Shiva, who are engaged in different tasks, purify you all: Time binds the hide, the Night of Destruction carries the skull in Shiva's hand, and the assembly of attendants is present when Shiva dances.

original: Skmsa /u /ka / / śatānandasya / Smvsū /mu / /
analyzed: śatānandasya smvsūmu
translated: [Sanskrit text]

original: śṛṅgaṃ bhṛṅgin vimuñca tyaja gajavadana tvaṃ ca lāṅgūlamūlaṃ mandānando 'si nandinn alam abala mahākāla kaṇṭhagraheṇa /
analyzed: śṛṅgam bhṛṅgin vimuñca tyaja gajavadana tvam ca lāṅgūla mūlam manda ānandaḥ si nandin alam abala mahākāla kaṇṭha graheṇa
translated: O Bhṛṅgin, release the peak, O Gajānana, leave the root of the tail, O Nandin, you are of little joy, O mighty Mahākāla, enough of embracing the neck.

original: ity uktvā nīyamānaḥ sukhayatu vṛṣabhaḥ pārvatīpādamūle paśyann akṣair vilakṣaṃ valitagalacalatkambalaṃ tryambakaṃ vaḥ // /
analyzed: iti uktvā nīyamānaḥ sukhayatu vṛṣabhaḥ pārvatī pāda mūle paśyan akṣaiḥ vilakṣam valita gala calat kambalam tryambakam vaḥ  /
translated: Having said this, may the bull, being led to the feet of Pārvatī, make you happy, seeing the three-eyed one, with a blanket moving from his neck, ashamed by the dice.

original: abhinandasya / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: abhinandasya
translated: [Sanskrit text]

original: gaurīvibhajyamānārdha saṃkīrṇe haramūrdhani /
analyzed: gaurī vibhajyamāna ardha saṃkīrṇe hara mūrdhani
translated: In the head of Hara, mixed with the half of Gaurī, which is divided,

original: amba dviguṇagambhīre bhāgīrathi namo 'stu te // / //
analyzed: amba dviguṇa gambhīre bhāgīrathi namaḥ stu te
translated: O Ambā, twice as deep, in the Bhagirathī, salutations to you.

original: kasyacit Skmsa /u /ka / / Smvsū /mu / /
analyzed: kasyacid skmsauka
translated: [Sanskrit text]

original: devasyāmbujasaṃbhavasya bhavanād ambhodhim āgāmukā seyaṃ maulivibhūṣaṇaṃ bhagavato bhargasya bhāgīrathī /
analyzed: devasya ambuja saṃbhavasya bhavanāt ambhodhim āgāmukā sā iyam mauli vibhūṣaṇam bhagavataḥ bhargasya bhāgīrathī
translated: This is the Bhagirathī, which comes from the abode of the lotus-born god, to the ocean, and is the crest-jewel of the blessed Bharga.

original: udyātān apahāya vigraham iha srotaḥpratīpān api srotas tīvrataratvarā gamayati drāg brahmalokaṃ janān // / //
analyzed: udyātān apahāya vigraham iha srotaḥ pratīpān api srotaḥ tīvratara tvarā gamayati drāk brahma lokam janān  /
translated: Leaving aside the agitated battle here, the current, even against the flow, quickly carries people to the world of Brahma due to its intense speed.

original: prātaḥ kālāñjanaparicitaṃ vīkṣya jāmātur oṣṭhaṃ kanyāyāś ca stanamukulayor aṅgulībhasmamudrāḥ /
analyzed: prātar kālāñjana paricitam vīkṣya jāmātuḥ oṣṭham kanyāyāḥ ca stana mukulayoḥ aṅgulī bhasma mudrāḥ
translated: Seeing the lips of the son-in-law smeared with morning collyrium and the ash-mark of the fingers on the buds of the breasts of the young woman,

original: premollāsāj jayati madhuraṃ sasmitābhir vadhūbhir gaurīmātuḥ kim api kim api vyāhṛtaṃ karṇamūle // / //
analyzed: prema ullāsāt jayati madhuram sa smitābhiḥ vadhūbhiḥ gaurīmātuḥ kim api kim api vyāhṛtam karṇa mūle
translated: the sweet words spoken by the smiling young brides to the mother of Gauri in the ear out of the joy of love are victorious.

original: śubhāṅgasya
analyzed: śubha aṅgasya
translated: Of Shubhaṅga:

original: lākṣārāgaṃ harati śikharāj jāhnavīvāri yeṣāṃ ye tatvanti srajam adhijaṭāmaṇḍalaṃ mālatīnām /
analyzed: lākṣā rāgam harati śikharāt jāhnavī vāri yeṣām ye tatvanti srajam adhi jaṭā maṇḍalam mālatīnām
translated: Those whose water from the Ganges removes the red dye from the crest-jewel, who wear a garland of jasmine flowers on their matted locks,

original: pratyutsarpadvimalakiraṇair yais tirodhānam indor devyāḥ sthāṇau caraṇapatite te nakhāḥ pāntu viśvam // / //
analyzed: pratyutsarpat vimala kiraṇaiḥ yaiḥ tirodhānam indoḥ devyāḥ sthāṇau caraṇa patite te nakhāḥ pāntu viśvam
translated: may the nails of those who cover the moon with their spreading pure rays and whose feet have fallen at the feet of the Goddess protect the universe.

original: dakṣasya / Skmsa /u /ka / / kasyacit
analyzed: dakṣasya skmsauka kasyacid
translated: Of Daksha. SkmSu.U.K. Of someone:

original: miśrībhūtāṃ tava tanulatāṃ bibhrato gauri kāmaṃ devasya syād aviralaparīrambhajanmā pramodaḥ /
analyzed: miśrībhūtām tava tanu latām bibhrataḥ gauri kāmam devasya syāt avirala parīrambha janmā pramodaḥ
translated: May there be uninterrupted joy born from frequent embraces of the god Shiva, who bears a body mixed with yours, O Gauri.

original: kintu premastimitamadhurasnigdhamugdhā na dṛṣṭir dṛṣṭety antaḥkaraṇam asakṛt tāmyati tryambakasya // / //
analyzed: kintu prema stimita madhura snigdha mugdhā na dṛṣṭiḥ dṛṣṭā iti antaḥkaraṇam asakṛt tāmyati tryambakasya  /
translated: But the heart of the three-eyed one is often troubled by the thought that he has not seen the eyes of the beloved, which are full of love, sweet, tender, and innocent.

original: bhagīrathasya / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: bhagīrathasya
translated: Of Bhagiratha.

original: avyād vo valikāṅghripātavicaladbhūgolahelonmukha bhrāmyaddikkarikalpitānukaraṇo nṛtyadgaṇagrāmaṇīḥ /
analyzed: avyāt vaḥ valikā aṅghri pāta vicalat bhū gola helā unmukha bhrāmyat dikkari kalpita anukaraṇaḥ nṛtyat gaṇa grāmaṇīḥ
translated: May the chief of the dancing Ganas protect you all, who, with the quarters of the sky for his dancing partners, dances with his head turned up, eager to play with the earth and the globe, which move when his feet fall on them.

original: yasyoddaṇḍitaśuṇḍapuṣkaramarudvyākṛṣṭasṛṣṭaṃ muhus tārācakraṃ udaktaśīkarapṛṣallīlām ivābhyasyati // / //
analyzed: yasya uddaṇḍita śuṇḍa puṣkara marut vyākṛṣṭa sṛṣṭam muhur tārā cakram udakta śīkara pṛṣat līlām iva abhyasyati  /
translated: By the wind from the trunk of his upraised tusk, he repeatedly draws out the circle of stars, as if practicing the sport of the spray of water rising upwards.

original: rājaśekharasya 🔽sānandaṃ nandihastāhatamurajaravāhūtakaumārabarhi trāsān nāsāgrarandhraṃ viśati phaṇipatau bhogasaṃkocabhāji /
analyzed: rājaśekharasya  sa ānandam nandi hasta āhata muraja rava āhūta kaumāra barhi trāsāt nāsā agra randhram viśati phaṇipatau bhoga saṃkoca bhāji
translated: Of Rajasekhara.

original: gaṇḍoḍḍīnālimālāmukharitakakubhas tāṇḍave śūlapāṇer vaināyakyaś ciraṃ vo vadanavidhutayaḥ pāntu cītkāravatyaḥ // / //
analyzed: gaṇḍa uḍḍīna ali mālā mukharita kakubhaḥ tāṇḍave śūlapāṇeḥ vaināyakyaḥ ciram vaḥ vadana vidhutayaḥ pāntu cītkāravatyaḥ  /  /
translated: May the cries of the Vinayakas, which come forth from the mouth of Shiva, the wielder of the trident, when the serpent, frightened by the sound of the drum beaten by the hand of Nandi, enters the nostril of the serpent, which contracts its coils, protect you all for a long time.

original: bhavabhūteḥ /
analyzed: bhavabhūteḥ
translated: Of Bhavabhuti.

original: mālatīmādhavamā /mā / /
analyzed: mālatī mādhava māmā
translated: Of the Malati-Madhava play.

original: yad ambā tāto vā dvayam idam agād ekatanutāṃ tadardhaṃ cārdhaṃ ca kva nu gatam athāryaḥ kathayatu /
analyzed: yat ambā tātaḥ vā dvayam idam agāt eka tanu tām tad ardham ca ardham ca kva nu gatam atha āryaḥ kathayatu
translated: When mother and father both became one body, where did the other half go? Let the noble one tell.

original: jagat tat taj jātaṃ sakalanaranārīmayam iti pratītiṃ kurvāṇo jayati śikhibhartur gajamukhaḥ // / //
analyzed: jagat tat tat jātam sakala nara nārī mayam iti pratītim kurvāṇaḥ jayati śikhi bhartuḥ gajamukhaḥ
translated: Making the world understand that it is full of men and women, the elephant-faced one, the lord of peacocks, is victorious.

original: bhavajaladhijalāvalambayaṣṭir mahiṣamahāsuraśailavajradhārā /
translated: The staff on which the world's ocean of existence leans, the thunderbolt in the mountain of the great demon Mahiṣa,

original: harahṛdayataḍāgarājahaṃsī diśatu śivaṃ jagataś ciram // / //🔽bhagīrathasya Skmsa /u /ka / /
analyzed: hara hṛdaya taḍāga rājahaṃsī diśatu śivam jagataḥ ciram  bhagīrathasya skmsauka
translated: The royal swan in the lake of Śiva's heart, may she bestow auspiciousness on the world for a long time.🔽Of Bhagīratha

original: bhagīrathadattasya
analyzed: bhagīrathadattasya
translated: Of Bhagīrathadatta

original: śūlāhatamahiṣāsurarudhiracchuritādharāmbarā gaurī /
analyzed: śūla āhata mahiṣa asura rudhira churita adhara ambarā gaurī
translated: Gaurī, whose lower garment is reddened by the blood of the demon Mahiṣa struck by the trident,

original: puṣpavatīva salajjā hasitaharanirīkṣitā jayati // / //
analyzed: puṣpavatī iva sa lajjā hasita hara nirīkṣitā jayati
translated: Blushing like a flowering vine, is looked at with a smile by Śiva. She is victorious.

original: gonandasya
analyzed: gonandasya
translated: Of Gonanda

original: pratyāsannavivāhamaṅgalavidhau devārcanavyastayā dṛṣṭvāgre pariṇetur eva likhitāṃ gaṅgādharasyākṛtim /
analyzed: pratyāsanna vivāha maṅgala vidhau deva arcana vyastayā dṛṣṭvā agre pariṇetuḥ eva likhitām gaṅgādharasya ākṛtim
translated: When she, busy with worshipping the gods, saw in front of her the image of her future husband drawn by her, at the time of the auspicious ceremonies for the approaching marriage,

original: unmādasmitaroṣalajjitam asau gauryā kathaṃcic cirād vṛddhastrīvacanāt priye vinihitaḥ puṣpāñjaliḥ pātu vaḥ // / //
analyzed: unmāda smita roṣa lajjitam asau gauryā kathaṃcid cirāt vṛddha strī vacanāt priye vinihitaḥ puṣpa añjaliḥ pātu vaḥ  /
translated: She, with difficulty, after a long time, with a smile of madness, anger and shyness, like an old woman, placed the handful of flowers on her beloved, may that protect you all.

original: bhāsasya / Skmsa /u /ka / /
analyzed: bhāsasya skmsauka
translated: Of Bhāsa.

original: Spdśā /pa / / Smvsū /mu / /
analyzed: sp dśāpa
translated: The end of the Smṛti Sūtra.

original: śikhipatir atidurlaḍitaḥ pitror abhilaṣati madhyam adhiśayitum /
analyzed: śikhipatiḥ ati durlaḍitaḥ pitroḥ abhilaṣati madhyam adhiśayitum
translated: The peacock lord, very spoiled, desires to lie down in the middle of his parents.

original: tāv apy ekaśarīrāv iti viṣamāśaś ciraṃ jayati // / //
analyzed: tau api eka śarīrau iti viṣama āśaḥ ciram jayati  /
translated: They too are of one body, so the uneven desire of him who is victorious for a long time...

original: ambeyaṃ neyam ambā na hi kharakapiśaṃ śmaśru tasyā mukhārdhe tāto 'yaṃ naiṣa tātaḥ stanaṃ urasi pitur dṛṣṭavān nāham atra /
analyzed: ambā iyam nā iyam ambā na hi khara kapiśam śmaśru tasyāḥ mukha ardhe tātaḥ yam nā eṣa tātaḥ stanam urasi pituḥ dṛṣṭavān na aham atra
translated: This is not my mother, for her face is covered with rough tawny beard; this is not my father, for I have never seen a breast on my father's chest.

original: keyaṃ ko 'yaṃ kiṃ etad yuvatir atha pumān vastu kiṃ syāt tṛtīyaṃ śambhoḥ saṃvīkṣya rūpād apasarati guhaḥ śaṅkitaḥ pātu yuṣmān // /🔽svecchāramyaṃ luṭhitvā pitur urasi citābhasmadhūlīcitāṅgo gaṅgāvāriṇy agādhe jhaṭiti harajaṭājūṭato dattajhampaḥ /
analyzed: kā iyam kaḥ yam kim etat yuvatiḥ atha pumān vastu kim syāt tṛtīyam śambhoḥ saṃvīkṣya rūpāt apasarati guhaḥ śaṅkitaḥ pātu yuṣmān  / svecchā ramyam luṭhitvā pituḥ urasi citā bhasma dhūlī cita aṅgaḥ gaṅgā vāriṇi agādhe jhaṭiti hara jaṭā jūṭataḥ datta jhampaḥ
translated: Who is this? Who is this? What is this? Is it a young woman or a man? Could it be a third thing? Seeing this form of Śambhu, Guha, frightened, runs away. May he protect you all...🔽Rolling about freely on his father's chest, his body covered with the ash-dust of the funeral pyre, suddenly jumping from the matted locks of Śiva into the unfathomable waters of the Ganges,

original: sadyaḥ sītkārakārī jalajaḍimaraṇahantapaṅktir guho vaḥ kampī pāyād apāyāj jvalitaśikhiśikhe cakṣuṣi nyastahastaḥ // /
analyzed: sadyas sītkāra kārī jala jaḍi maraṇa hanta paṅktiḥ guhaḥ vaḥ kampī pāyāt apāyāt jvalita śikhi śikhe cakṣuṣi nyasta hastaḥ  /
translated: May Guha protect you all, making a hissing sound, with a row of teeth white like snow, trembling, with his hand placed in his flaming eye, having come and gone...🔽Of Bāṇa.

original: bāṇasya / Skmsa /u /ka / / Smvsū /mu / /
analyzed: bāṇasya skmsauka
translated: The end of the Smṛti Sūtra.

original: haṃsaśreṇikutūhalena kalayan bhūṣākapālāvalīṃ bālām indukalāṃ mṛṇālarabhasād āndolayan pāṇinā /
analyzed: haṃsa śreṇi kutūhalena kalayan bhūṣā kapāla āvalīm bālām indu kalām mṛṇāla rabhasāt āndolayan pāṇinā
translated: With the curiosity of a row of swans, he counts the garland of ornaments, and with his hand, he shakes the young moon-crescent with the speed of a lotus stalk.

original: raktāmbhojadhiyā ca locanapuṭaṃ lālāṭam udghāṭayan pāyād vaḥ pitur aṅkabhāk śiśujanakrīḍonmukhaḥ ṣaṇmukhaḥ // / //
analyzed: rakta ambhoja dhiyā ca locana puṭam lālāṭam udghāṭayan pāyāt vaḥ pituḥ aṅka bhāj śiśu jana krīḍā unmukhaḥ ṣaṇmukhaḥ  /
translated: And with the idea of a red lotus, he opens his forehead with his eyes. May that six-faced one, eager to play with the children, who sits on his father's lap, protect you all.

original: balabhadrasya / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: balabhadrasya
translated: Of Balabhadra.

original: kapolād uḍḍīnair bhayavaśavilolair madhukarair madāmbhaḥsaṃlobhād upari patituṃ baddhapaṭalaiḥ /
analyzed: kapolāt uḍḍīnaiḥ bhaya vaśa vilolaiḥ madhukaraiḥ mada ambhaḥ saṃlobhāt upari patitum baddha paṭalaiḥ
translated: The bees, frightened and fluttering, have flown up from his cheeks, forming a canopy above, out of greed for the nectar.

original: caladbarhacchatraśriyam iva dadhāno 'tirucirām avighnaṃ herambo jagadaghavighātaṃ ghaṭayatu // / //
analyzed: calat barha chatra śriyam iva dadhānaḥ tiru cirām avighnam herambaḥ jagat agha vighātam ghaṭayatu  /
translated: Bearing the beauty of a moving peacock-feather umbrella, may the auspicious Ganesha accomplish the destruction of the world's sins without hindrance.

original: Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: skmsauka
translated: Of Skandasundara.

original: ekaḥ sa eva paripālayatāj jaganti gaurīgirīśacaritānukṛtiṃ dadhānaḥ /
analyzed: ekaḥ saḥ eva paripālayatāt jaganti gaurī girīśa carita anukṛtim dadhānaḥ
translated: May that single one, who bears the imitation of the conduct of Shiva and Parvati, protect the worlds.

original: ābhāti yo daśanaśūnyamukhaikadeśa dehārdhahāritavadhūka ivakadantaḥ // / //🔽Skmsa /u /ka / / vasukalpasya
analyzed: ābhāti yaḥ daśana śūnya mukha eka deśa deha ardha hārita vadhūkaḥ iva kadantaḥ 🔽vasu kalpasya
translated: He shines with one side of his face empty due to the absence of teeth, like a man with only half a tooth left from his wife taking away the other half.

original: arciṣmanti vidārya vaktrakuharāṇy āsṛkkvaṇo vāsukes tarjanyā viṣakarburān gaṇayataḥ saṃspṛśya dantāṅkurān /
analyzed: arciṣmanti vidārya vaktra kuharāṇi vāsukeḥ tarjanyāḥ viṣa karburān gaṇayataḥ saṃspṛśya danta aṅkurān
translated: Piercing through the flaming cavities of the mouths, counting the teeth sprouts mottled with poison, with the index finger of Vasuki,

original: ekaṃ trīṇi navāṣṭa sapta ṣaḍativyastāstasaṃkhyākramā vācaḥ śaktidharasya śaiśavakalāḥ kurvantu vo maṅgalam // / //🔽Skmsa /u /ka / / Spdśā /pa /
analyzed: ekam trīṇi nava aṣṭa sapta ṣaṣ ati vyastāḥ ta saṃkhyā kramāḥ vācaḥ śaktidharasya śaiśava kalāḥ kurvantu vaḥ maṅgalam  /  sp sp sauka
translated: The words of Shakra, the wielder of the thunderbolt, one, three, nine, eight, seven, six, mixed up in reverse order, may bring you auspiciousness, O children.

original: suptaṃ pakṣapuṭe nilīnaśirasaṃ sṛṣṭvā mayūraṃ puraḥ kṛttaṃ kena śiro 'sya tāta katham ity ākrandataḥ śaiśavāt /
