translated: The good are like trees, bearing fruit for the benefit of others.

original: apekṣante na ca snehaṃ na pātraṃ na daśāntaram /
analyzed: apekṣante na ca sneham na pātram na daśāntaram
translated: They do not expect affection, a worthy recipient, or a good time.

original: sadā lokahite saktā ratnadīpā ivottamāḥ // / //
analyzed: sadā loka hite saktāḥ ratna dīpāḥ iva uttamāḥ
translated: Always devoted to the welfare of the world, the best are like jewel lamps.

original: lakṣmīṃ tṛṇāya manyante tadbhareṇa namanti ca /
analyzed: lakṣmīm tṛṇāya manyante tad bhareṇa namanti ca
translated: They consider wealth as straw, and bow down under its burden.

original: aho kim api citrāṇi caritrāṇi mahātmanām // / //
analyzed: aho kim api citrāṇi caritrāṇi mahātmanām
translated: Oh, the wonderful deeds of the great ones!

original: añjalisthāni puṣpāṇi vāsayanti karadvayam /
analyzed: añjali sthāni puṣpāṇi vāsayanti kara dvayam
translated: Flowers held in the palms perfume both hands.

original: aho sumanasāṃ vṛttir vāmadakṣiṇayoḥ samā // / //
analyzed: aho sumanasām vṛttiḥ vāma dakṣiṇayoḥ samā
translated: Oh, the even conduct of the good, whether on the left or the right.

original: paraguṇatattvagrahaṇaṃ svaguṇāvaraṇaṃ paravyasanamaunam /
analyzed: para guṇa tattva grahaṇam sva guṇa āvaraṇam para vyasana maunam
translated: The truth of others' qualities is grasped, one's own qualities are concealed, and one is silent about others' misfortunes.

original: madhuram aśaṭhaṃ ca vākyaṃ kenāpy upadiṣṭam āryāṇām // / //
analyzed: madhuram a śaṭham ca vākyam kena api upadiṣṭam āryāṇām
translated: Sweet and sincere speech has been taught by someone to the noble ones.

original: vicintyamāno hi karoti vismayaṃ visāriṇā saccaritena sajjanaḥ /
analyzed: vicintyamānaḥ hi karoti vismayam visāriṇā sat caritena sat janaḥ
translated: For a good person, when reflected upon, causes wonder with his spreading good conduct.

original: yadā tu cakṣuḥpatham eti dehināṃ tadāmṛteneva manāṃsi siñcati // / //🔽saṃparkeṇa tamobhidāṃ jagadaghapradhvaṃsināṃ dhīmatāṃ krūro 'pi prakṛtaṃ vihāya malinām ālambate bhadratām /
analyzed: yadā tu cakṣuḥ patham eti dehinām tadā amṛtena iva manāṃsi siñcati  / saṃparkeṇa tamaḥ bhidām jagat agha pradhvaṃsinām dhīmatām prakṛtam vihāya malinām ālambate bhadra tām
translated: But when he comes within the range of sight of embodied beings, he sprinkles their minds as if with nectar.🔽Even a cruel person, by association with the wise, destroyers of darkness and the sins of the world, abandons his natural wickedness and adopts goodness.

original: yat tṛṣṇāglapito 'pi necchati janaḥ pātuṃ tad eva kṣaṇād ujjhaty ambudharodarasthitam apāṃ patyuḥ payaḥ kṣāratām // /
analyzed: yat tṛṣṇā glapitaḥ api nā icchati janaḥ pātum tat eva kṣaṇāt ujjhati ambudhara udara sthitam apām patyuḥ payaḥ kṣāra tām  /
translated: That very water which a thirsty person does not wish to drink, he immediately abandons when it is in the belly of a cloud, having become salty.

original: kvākarāṇāruṣāṃ saṃkhyā saṃkhyātāḥ kāraṇakrudhaḥ /
analyzed: kvākarāṇa aruṣām saṃkhyā saṃkhyātāḥ kāraṇa krudhaḥ
translated: Where are the countable causes of anger of the angry ones,

original: kāraṇe 'pi na kupyanti ye te jagati pañcaṣāḥ // / //🔽sujanāḥ paruṣābhidhāyino yadi kaḥ syād aparo 'pi mañjuvāk /
analyzed: kāraṇe pi na kupyanti ye te jagati pañcaṣāḥ  su janāḥ paruṣa abhidhāyinaḥ yadi kaḥ syāt mañju vāc
translated: Those five or six in the world who do not get angry even at a cause.🔽If good people are harsh-speaking, who else would be a sweet-speaker?

original: yadi candrakarāḥ savahnayo nanu jāyeta sudhā kṛto 'nyataḥ // / //
analyzed: yadi candrakarāḥ sa vahnayaḥ nanu jāyeta sudhā kṛtaḥ nyatas
translated: And if the moonbeams were to be fiery, would nectar not be produced from elsewhere?

original: maṅgalasya //
analyzed: maṅgalasya
translated: Of Mangala.

original: ye dīneṣu kṛpālavaḥ spṛśati yān alpo 'pi na śrīmadaḥ śrāntā ye ca paropakārakaraṇe hṛṣyanti ye yācitāḥ /
analyzed: ye dīneṣu kṛpālavaḥ spṛśati yān na śrīmadaḥ śrāntāḥ ye ca para upakāra karaṇe hṛṣyanti ye yācitāḥ
translated: Those who are kind to the poor, whom even a little wealth does not touch, who are tired of doing favors to others, who rejoice when asked,

original: svasthāḥ saty api yauvanodayamahāvyādhiprakope 'pi ye te bhūmaṇḍalamaṇḍanaikatilakāḥ santaḥ kiyanto janāḥ // / //
analyzed: svasthāḥ sati api yauvana udaya mahā vyādhi prakope ye te bhū maṇḍala maṇḍana eka tilakāḥ santaḥ kiyantaḥ janāḥ  /
translated: There are only a few good people in the world who remain calm even when the great disease of youth is raging.

original: yaśo rakṣanti na prāṇān pāpād bibhati na dviṣaḥ /
analyzed: yaśaḥ rakṣanti na prāṇān pāpāt bibhati na dviṣaḥ
translated: They protect their fame, not their lives; they fear sin, not enemies.

original: anviṣyanty arthino nārthān nisargo 'yaṃ mahātmanām // / //🔽yathā yathā parāṃ koṭir guṇaḥ samadhirohati /
analyzed: anviṣyanti arthinaḥ na arthāt nisargaḥ yam mahātmanām  yathā yathā parām koṭiḥ guṇaḥ samadhirohati
translated: They seek wealth for the needy, not for themselves - this is the nature of the great.🔽As the highest degree of virtue is attained,

original: santaḥ kodaṇḍadharmāṇo viramanti tathā tathā // / //
analyzed: santaḥ kodaṇḍa dharmāṇaḥ viramanti tathā tathā
translated: the good, like the bow, become more and more relaxed.

original: ayaṃ nijaḥ paro veti gaṇanā laghucetasām /
analyzed: ayam nijaḥ paraḥ vā iti gaṇanā laghu cetasām
translated: The calculation this is mine, that is another's is for the small-minded.

original: udāracaritānāṃ tu vasudhaiva kuṭumbakam // / //🔽ye prāpte vyasane 'py anākuladhiyaḥ saṃpatsu naivonnatāḥ prāpte naiva parāṅmukhāḥ praṇayini prāṇopayogair api /
analyzed: udāra caritānām tu vasudhā eva kuṭumbakam  ye prāpte vyasane pi an ākula dhiyaḥ saṃpatsu nā eva unnatāḥ prāpte nā eva parāṅmukhāḥ praṇayini prāṇa upayogaiḥ api
translated: But for the magnanimous, the whole earth is their family.🔽Those whose minds are undisturbed even when calamity strikes, who are not elevated by prosperity, who do not turn away from a friend even at the cost of their lives,

original: hrīmantaḥ svaguṇapraśaṃsanavidhāv anyastutau paṇḍitā dhig dhātrā kṛpaṇena yena na kṛtāḥ kalpāntadīrghāyuṣaḥ // / //
analyzed: hrīmantaḥ sva guṇa praśaṃsana vidhau anya stutau paṇḍitāḥ dhik dhātrā kṛpaṇena yena na kṛtāḥ kalpa anta dīrgha āyuṣaḥ  /
translated: who are modest, wise in praising others' virtues, alas, the creator has made them short-lived, out of miserliness.

original: kare ślāghyas tyāgaḥ śirasi gurupādapraṇayitā mukhe satyā vāṇī śrutam anavagītaṃ śravaṇayoḥ /
analyzed: kare ślāghyaḥ tyāgaḥ śirasi guru pāda praṇayi tā mukhe satyā vāṇī śrutam anavagītam śravaṇayoḥ
translated: In the hand, generosity is praiseworthy; on the head, devotion to the feet of the guru; in the mouth, truthful speech; in the ears, learning that is not vainglorious.

original: hṛdi svacchā vṛttir vijayibhujayor vīryam atulaṃ vināpy aiśvaryeṇa sphurati mahatāṃ maṇḍanam idam // / //
analyzed: hṛdi su acchā vṛttiḥ vijayi bhujayoḥ vīryam atulam vinā api aiśvaryeṇa sphurati mahatām maṇḍanam idam  /
translated: In the heart, pure conduct; in the victorious arms, incomparable valor - this is the ornament of the great, shining forth even without great wealth.

original: nītiśataka
analyzed: nītiśataka
translated: The Hundred Verses on Wisdom

original: vajrād api kaṭhorāṇi mṛdūni kusumād api /
analyzed: vajrāt api kaṭhorāṇi mṛdūni kusumāt api
translated: Even harder than a diamond, softer than a flower,

original: lokottarāṇāṃ cetāṃsi ko hi vijñātum arhati // / //
analyzed: lokottarāṇām cetāṃsi kaḥ hi vijñātum arhati  /
translated: who can understand the minds of the supermundane?

original: bhavabhūteḥ u /rā /ca / /
analyzed: bhavabhūteḥ urāca
translated: By Bhavabhuti, U.R.A.C.

original: ā paritoṣād viduṣāṃ na sādhu manye prayogavijñānam /
analyzed: ā paritoṣāt viduṣām na sādhu manye prayoga vijñānam
translated: I do not consider the knowledge of composition to be good enough to satisfy the wise.

original: balavad api śikṣitānām ātmany apratyayaṃ cetaḥ // / //
analyzed: balavat api śikṣitānām ātmani apratyayam cetaḥ  /
translated: Even for the well-trained, the mind is unreliable in itself.

original: śākuntala /
analyzed: śākuntala
translated: Shakūntala.

original: purāṇam ity eva na sādhu sarvaṃ na cāpi kāvyaṃ navam ity avadyam /
analyzed: purāṇam iti eva na sādhu sarvam na ca api kāvyam navam iti avadyam
translated: Not everything is good just because it is ancient, nor is a new poem necessarily faulty.

original: santaḥ parīkṣyānyatarad bhajante mūḍhaḥ parapratyayahāryabuddhiḥ // / //
analyzed: santaḥ parīkṣya anyatarat bhajante mūḍhaḥ para pratyaya hārya buddhiḥ
translated: The good examine and then follow one or the other; the fool's mind is swayed by the opinions of others.

original: kālidāsasyaitau ma /a /mi / /
analyzed: kālidāsasya etau ma ami
translated: By Kālidāsa, these are M.A.M.

original: guhyapidhānaikaparaḥ sujano vastrāyate sadā piśunam /
analyzed: guhya pidhāna eka paraḥ su janaḥ vastrāyate sadā piśunam
translated: The good man, ever intent on concealing his secrets, always covers the slanderer with a garment.

original: bhavatām ayaṃ viḍambo yad idaṃ chidrair visūtrayatu // / //
analyzed: bhavatām ayam viḍambaḥ yat idam chidraiḥ visūtrayatu
translated: This is your deception, that you string them together with holes.

original: brūta nūtanakūṣmāṇḍa phalānāṃ ke bhavanty amī /
analyzed: brūta nūtana kūṣmāṇḍa phalānām ke bhavanti amī
translated: Tell me, who are these of the new pumpkin fruit?

original: aṅgulīkathanād eva yan na jīvanti māninaḥ // / //
analyzed: aṅgulī kathanāt eva yat na jīvanti māninaḥ
translated: That the proud do not live even by the mention of fingers.

original: yan netrais tribhir īkṣate na giriśo nāṣṭābhir apy abjabhūḥ sakndo dvādaśabhis na vā na maghavā cakṣuḥsahasreṇa vā /
analyzed: yat netraiḥ tribhiḥ īkṣate na giriśaḥ na aṣṭābhiḥ api abja bhūḥ sakndaḥ dvādaśabhiḥ na vā na maghavā cakṣuḥ sahasreṇa vā
translated: That Śiva does not see with three eyes, Brahmā with eight, Skanda with twelve, nor Indra with a thousand eyes.

original: saṃbhūyāpi jagattrayasya nayanair draṣṭuṃ na yat śakyate pratyādiśya dṛśau samāhitadhiyaḥ paśyanti tatpaṇḍitāḥ // / //
analyzed: saṃbhūya api jagattrayasya nayanaiḥ draṣṭum na yat śakyate pratyādiśya dṛśau samāhita dhiyaḥ paśyanti tat paṇḍitāḥ  /
translated: That which cannot be seen even by the eyes of the three worlds combined, the wise see by turning their eyes and concentrating their minds.

original: kasyacit / Skmsa /u /ka / /
analyzed: kasyacid
translated: Of someone.

original: śālikanāthasya
analyzed: śālikanāthasya
translated: Of Śālikanātha.

original: nīrasāny api rocante karpāsasya phalāni naḥ /🔽yeṣāṃ guṇamayaṃ janma pareṣāṃ guhyaguptaye // / //
analyzed: nīrasāni api rocante karpāsasya phalāni naḥ  yeṣām guṇa mayam janma pareṣām guhya guptaye
translated: Even tasteless things please us, the fruits of cotton.🔽Whose birth is full of virtues for the protection of others' secrets.

original: guṇavatpātra mātraika hāryaniryāsam āśayan /
analyzed: guṇavat pātra mātra eka hārya niryāsam
translated: Desiring to take away the essence that can only be taken by a worthy vessel,

original: ātmanāvaiti te lokaḥ svabandhur iti dhāvati // / //
analyzed: ātmanā avaiti te lokaḥ sva bandhuḥ iti dhāvati  /
translated: The world considers you as its own kinsman and runs to you.

original: satatam asatyād bibhyati mā bhaiṣīr iti vadanti bhīteṣu /
analyzed: satatam asatyāt bibhyati mā bhaiṣīḥ iti vadanti bhīteṣu
translated: To the frightened they say, Do not be afraid, always afraid of untruth.

original: atithijanaśeṣam aśnati sajjanajihve kṛtāthāsi // / //
analyzed: atithi jana śeṣam aśnati sat jana jihve kṛtā atha asi
translated: O tongue of the good, you eat what is left over by guests.

original: yady api daivāt sneho naśyati sādhos tathāpi sattveṣu /
analyzed: yadi api daivāt snehaḥ naśyati sādhoḥ tathā api sattveṣu
translated: Even if affection towards the virtuous is destroyed by fate, it still persists in beings.

original: ghaṇṭādhvaner ivāntaś ciram anubadhnāti saṃskāraḥ // / //
analyzed: ghaṇṭā dhvaneḥ iva antar ciram anubadhnāti saṃskāraḥ
translated: The impression (of affection) remains within for a long time, like the bell of a bell-ringer.

original: raviguptasya
analyzed: raviguptasya
translated: Of Ravi Gupta.

original: iti sadvrajyā ////
analyzed: iti sat vrajyā
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the virtuous.

original: tato 'sadvrajyā
analyzed: sat vrajyā
translated: Then begins the chapter on the non-virtuous.

original: atimaline kartavye bhavati khalānām atīva nipuṇā dhīḥ /
analyzed: ati maline kartavye bhavati khalānām atīva nipuṇā dhīḥ
translated: In a very dirty task, the intellect of the wicked becomes extremely skillful.

original: timire hi kauśikānāṃ rūpaṃ pratipadyante dṛṣṭiḥ // / //
analyzed: timire hi kauśikānām rūpam pratipadyante dṛṣṭiḥ
translated: For in darkness, the eyes of owls attain form.

original: sadguṇālaṃkṛte kāvye doṣān mṛgayate khalaḥ /
analyzed: sat guṇa alaṃkṛte kāvye doṣān mṛgayate khalaḥ
translated: In a poem adorned with good qualities, the wicked look for faults.

original: vane puṣpakalākīrṇaḥ karabhaḥ kaṇṭakān iva // / //🔽mukharasyāprasannasya mitrakāryavighātinaḥ /🔽nirmāṇam āśānāśāya durjanasya ghanasya ca // / //
analyzed: vane puṣpa kalā ākīrṇaḥ karabhaḥ kaṇṭakān iva  mukharasya aprasannasya mitra kārya vighātinaḥ  nirmāṇam āśā nāśāya durjanasya ghanasya ca
translated: Like a camel in a forest strewn with flowers, he seeks out thorns.🔽The creation of a loud, displeased, and obstructive friend🔽is for the destruction of hope, of a dense and wicked person.

original: nirvāte vyajanaṃ madāndhakariṇāṃ darpopaśāntau śṛṇiḥ poto dustaravārirāśitaraṇe dīpo 'ndhakārāgame /
analyzed: nirvāte vyajanam mada andha kariṇām darpa upaśāntau śṛṇiḥ potaḥ dustara vāri rāśi taraṇe dīpaḥ ndhakāra āgame
translated: A fan in a windless place, a goad to a maddened elephant, a boat to cross a vast ocean, a lamp in the darkness,

original: itthaṃ tad bhuvi nāsti yatra vidhinā nopāyacintā kṛtā manye durjanacittavṛttiharaṇe dhātāpi bhagnodyamaḥ // / //
analyzed: ittham tat bhuvi nā asti yatra vidhinā nā upāya cintā kṛtā manye durjana cittavṛtti haraṇe dhātā api bhagna udyamaḥ  /
translated: Thus, there is nothing on earth where the Creator has not employed his ingenuity. I think even the Creator has failed in his efforts to take away the wickedness from the minds of the wicked.

original: akāraṇāviṣkṛtavairadāruṇād asajjanāt kasya bhayaṃ na jāyate /
analyzed: akāraṇa āviṣkṛta vaira dāruṇāt asat janāt kasya bhayam na jāyate
translated: From the wicked person whose enmity is displayed without reason, who does not fear?

original: viṣaṃ mahāher iva yasya durvacaḥ suduḥsahaṃ saṃnihitaṃ sadā mukhe // / //
analyzed: viṣam mahā aheḥ iva yasya durvacaḥ su duḥsaham saṃnihitam sadā mukhe
translated: Whose harsh words are as unbearable as the poison of a great serpent, always present in his mouth?

original: khalavṛndaṃ śmaśānaṃ ca bhavaty apacitaṃ yadā /
analyzed: khala vṛndam śmaśānam ca bhavati apacitam yadā
translated: When a group of wicked people and a cremation ground become emaciated,

original: dhruvaṃ tadaiva lokānāṃ kalyāṇam avagamyate // / //🔽antarmalinadehena bahir āhlādakāriṇā /
analyzed: dhruvam tadā eva lokānām kalyāṇam avagamyate  / antar malina dehena bahis āhlāda kāriṇā
translated: then it is certainly understood that good fortune has come to the people.🔽Who has not been deceived by a wicked person, whose body is internally impure but externally delightful,

original: mahākālaphaleneva kaḥ khalena na vañcitaḥ // / //
analyzed: mahākāla phalena iva kaḥ khalena na vañcitaḥ
translated: like the fruit of the great-time tree?

original: sarvatraiva khalo janaḥ saralatāsadbhāvaniḥsaṅgināṃ sādhūnāṃ padabandhanāya piśunaprauḍhābhimānodyamaḥ /
analyzed: sarvatra eva khalaḥ janaḥ sarala tā sadbhāva niḥsaṅginām sādhūnām pada bandhanāya piśuna prauḍha abhimāna udyamaḥ
translated: Everywhere, the wicked person, with a mature sense of slander, is ready to bind the feet of the simple, good-natured, and detached sages.

original: sūtraṃ kiṃcid apūrvam eva jaṭharād utpādya sadyaḥ svayaṃ lūtātantuvitānajālakuṭilaṃ cakraṃ karoty adbhutam // / //
analyzed: sūtram kiṃcid apūrvam eva jaṭharāt utpādya sadyas svayam lūtā tantu vitāna jāla kuṭilam cakram karoti adbhutam  /
translated: Having produced some new thread from his belly, he himself creates a wonderful wheel, crooked like the web of spider threads.

original: devānām api paśyantāṃ sa śriyā medhyate khalu /
analyzed: devānām api paśyantām sa śriyā medhyate khalu
translated: Even the gods see that he is indeed honored with glory.

original: vāsasāpi na yogo 'sti niścakrasya pinākinaḥ // / //
analyzed: vāsasā api na yogaḥ sti niścakrasya pinākinaḥ
translated: There is no connection even with a cloth for the Pinaka-bearer who is without a chariot.

original: stokenonnatim āyāti stokenāyāty adhogatim /
analyzed: stokena unnatim āyāti stokena āyāti adhogatim
translated: One rises high with a little (good deed), one falls down with a little (bad deed).

original: aho na sadṛśī vṛttis tulākoṭeḥ khalasya ca // / //
analyzed: aho na sadṛśī vṛttiḥ tulā koṭeḥ khalasya ca
translated: Oh! How similar is the behavior of the tip of a scale and a wicked person!

original: ākhubhyaḥ kiṃ khalair jñātaṃ khalebhyaḥ kim athākhubhiḥ /
analyzed: ākhubhyaḥ kim khalaiḥ jñātam khalebhyaḥ kim atha ākhubhiḥ
translated: What have wicked people learned from mice, and what have mice learned from wicked people?

original: anyad pt paragṛhotkhātāt karma yeṣāṃ na vidyate // / //
analyzed: anyat para gṛha utkhātāt karma yeṣām na vidyate  /
translated: They have no other work than digging up other people's houses.

original: durjanadūṣitamanasāṃ puṃsāṃ svajane 'pi nāsti viśvāsaḥ /
analyzed: durjana dūṣita manasām puṃsām sva jane na asti viśvāsaḥ
translated: For men whose minds are corrupted by evil people, there is no trust even in their own people.

original: bālaḥ pāyasadagdho dadhy api phūtkṛtya bhakṣayati // / //
analyzed: bālaḥ pāyasa dagdhaḥ dadhi api phūtkṛtya bhakṣayati  /
translated: A child, burnt by milk pudding, blows on curd and eats it.

original: guṇotkarṣadveṣād pt prakṛtimahatām apy asadṛśaṃ khalaḥ kiṃcid vākyaṃ racayati ca vistārayati ca /
analyzed: guṇa utkarṣa dveṣāt prakṛti mahatām api a sadṛśam khalaḥ kiṃcid vākyam racayati ca vistārayati ca
translated: Out of hatred for the excellence of virtues, a wicked person composes and spreads some statement that is not equal to even a fraction of the greatness of nature.

original: na ced evaṃ tādṛk kamalakalikārdhapratinidhau muneḥgr gaṇḍūṣe 'bdhiḥ sthita iti kuto 'yaṃ kalakalaḥ // / //
analyzed: na ced evam tādṛś kamala kalikā ardha pratinidhau gaṇḍūṣe bdhiḥ sthitaḥ iti kutas yam kalakalaḥ  /
translated: If it were not so, then why is there this commotion over the statement that the ocean is contained in the sage's mouth, which is a substitute for half of a lotus bud?

original: priyasakhi vipaddaṇḍaprāntaprapātaparamparā paricayacale cintācakre nidhāya vidhiḥ khalaḥ /
analyzed: priya sakhi vipad daṇḍa prānta prapāta paramparā paricaya cale cintā cakre nidhāya vidhiḥ khalaḥ
translated: O dear friend, having placed the series of falls at the end of the rod of misfortune in the unsteady wheel of thoughts due to familiarity, fate, the wicked one,

original: mṛdam iva balāt piṇḍīkṛtya pragalbhakulākavad bhramayati mano no jānīmaḥ kim atra vidhāsyati // / //
analyzed: mṛdam iva balāt piṇḍīkṛtya pragalbha kulāka vat bhramayati manaḥ naḥ jānīmaḥ kim atra vidhāsyati  /
translated: Like clay, he forcibly forms a lump and whirls it around like a skilled potter. We do not know what he will do with it.

original: pādāhato 'tha dhṛtadaṇḍavighaṭṭito vā yaṃ daṃṣṭrayā spṛśati taṃ kila hanti sarpaḥ /
analyzed: dhṛta daṇḍa vighaṭṭitaḥ vā yam daṃṣṭrayā spṛśati tam kila hanti sarpaḥ
translated: If bitten by a foot, struck by a stick, or touched by its fangs, it is said that the snake kills.

original: ko 'py anya eṣa piśuno 'tra bhujaṅgadharmā karṇe paraṃ spṛśati hanty aparaṃ samūlam // / //
analyzed: kaḥ pi anyaḥ eṣa bhujaṅga dharmā karṇe param spṛśati hanti aparam sa mūlam
translated: But this other slanderer, who acts like a snake, touches one in the ear and kills another from the root.

original: pariśuddhām api vṛttiṃ samāśrito durjanaḥ parān vyathate /
analyzed: pariśuddhām api vṛttim samāśritaḥ durjanaḥ parān vyathate
translated: Even relying on a pure livelihood, a bad person torments others.

original: pavanāśino 'pi bhujagāḥ paropaghātaṃ na muñcanti // / //
analyzed: pavana āśinaḥ pi bhujagāḥ para upaghātam na muñcanti  /
translated: Even snakes that eat air do not abandon harming others.

original: raviguptasya
analyzed: raviguptasya
translated: Of Ravigupta

original: agamyo mantrāṇāṃ prakṛtibhiṣajām apy aviṣayaḥ sudhāsārāsādhyo visadṛśatarārambhagahanaḥ /
analyzed: agamyaḥ mantrāṇām prakṛti bhiṣajām api aviṣayaḥ sudhā sāra asādhyaḥ visadṛśatara ārambha gahanaḥ
translated: Unreachable by mantras, beyond the scope of natural physicians, unachievable by the essence of nectar, with a beginning that is extremely different,

original: jagad bhrāmīkartuṃ pariṇatadhiyānena vidhinā sphuṭaṃ sṛṣṭo vyādhiḥ prakṛtiviṣamo durjanajanaḥ // / //
analyzed: jagat bhrāmīkartum pariṇata dhiyā anena vidhinā sphuṭam sṛṣṭaḥ vyādhiḥ prakṛti viṣamaḥ durjana janaḥ  /
translated: This disease, created by this method by the one with mature wisdom, is clearly meant to confuse the world. It is a bad person, born with a nature that is contrary to that of a good person.

original: yaḥ svān api prathamam astasamastasādhu vṛttir guṇān khalatayā malinīkaroti /
analyzed: yaḥ svān api prathamam asta samasta sādhu vṛttiḥ guṇān khala tayā malinīkaroti
translated: He who, first of all, by his wickedness, defiles even his own virtues, which are entirely good,

original: tasyāsya bhogina ivograruṣaḥ khalasya dākṣiṇyam asti katham anyaguṇopamarde // / //
analyzed: tasya asya bhoginaḥ iva ugra ruṣaḥ khalasya dākṣiṇyam asti katham anya guṇa upamarde
translated: How can there be courtesy in him, like that of a fierce serpent, who destroys the virtues of others?

original: randhrānveṣiṇi duṣṭadṛṣṭiviṣiṇi svacchāśayadveṣiṇi kṣipre roṣiṇi śarmaśoṣiṇe vinā hetuṃ jagatploṣiṇi /
analyzed: randhra anveṣiṇi duṣṭa dṛṣṭi viṣiṇi svaccha āśaya dveṣiṇi kṣipre roṣiṇi śarma śoṣiṇe vinā hetum jagat ploṣiṇi
translated: Searching for loopholes, possessing the poisonous sight of evil, hating pure intentions, quickly angered, drying up happiness, burning the world without cause,

original: svārthārthaṃ mṛdubhāṣiṇīṣṭavihatav ekāntatas toṣiṇi śreyaḥ kruddhabhujaṅgabhogaviṣame saṃvidyate kiṃ khale // / //
analyzed: sva artha artham mṛdu bhāṣiṇi iṣṭa vihato ekāntataḥ toṣiṇi śreyaḥ kruddha bhujaṅga bhoga viṣame saṃvidyate kim khale  /
translated: Speaking sweetly for self-interest, extremely satisfied when desired things are accomplished, what good is there in a wicked person, who is like the poisonous coils of an angry snake?

original: guṇākarasya śleṣaślokau
analyzed: guṇākarasya śleṣa ślokau
translated: Two alliterative verses on the mine of virtues

original: jāḍyaṃ hrīmati gaṇyate vratarucau dambhaḥ śucau kaitavaṃ śūre nirghṛṇatārjave vimatinā dainyaṃ priyālāpini /
analyzed: jāḍyam hrīmati gaṇyate vrata rucau dambhaḥ śucau kaitavam śūre nirghṛṇa tā ārjave vimatinā dainyam priya ālāpini
translated: In a modest person, dullness is considered, in one who delights in vows, hypocrisy, in a pure person, deceit, in a hero, cruelty, in an honest person, doubt, in a sweet-talker, dejection.

original: tejasviny avaliptatā mukharatā vaktary aśaktiḥ sthire tat ko nāma bhaved guṇaḥ sa guṇināṃ yo durjane nāṅkitaḥ // / //
analyzed: tejasvini avalipta tā mukhara tā vaktari aśaktiḥ sthire tat kaḥ nāma bhavet guṇaḥ sa guṇinām yaḥ durjane nā aṅkitaḥ  /
translated: In a brilliant person, arrogance, in a eloquent person, loquacity, in a steadfast person, incapacity - what indeed is that virtue of the virtuous which is not branded by the wicked?

original: vandyān nindati duḥkhitān upahasaty ābādhate bāndhavān śūrān dveṣṭi dhanacyutān paribhavaty ājñāpayaty āśritān /
analyzed: vandyān nindati duḥkhitān upahasati ābādhate bāndhavān śūrān dveṣṭi dhana cyutān paribhavati ājñāpayati āśritān
translated: He censures the venerable, laughs at the afflicted, torments his relatives, hates the brave, humiliates the fallen, commands the dependent,

original: guhyāni prakaṭīkaroti ghaṭayaty anyonyavairāśrayān brūte śīghram avācyam ujjhitaguṇo gṛhṇāti doṣān khalaḥ // / //
analyzed: guhyāni prakaṭīkaroti ghaṭayati anyonya vaira āśrayān brūte śīghram avācyam ujjhita guṇaḥ gṛhṇāti doṣān khalaḥ  /
translated: He reveals secrets, brings about mutual enmities, speaks quickly what should not be said, and takes on faults, a scoundrel abandoning virtues.

original: yad yad iṣṭataraṃ tat tad deyaṃ guṇavate kila /
analyzed: yat yat iṣṭataram tat tat deyam guṇavate kila
translated: It is said that whatever is most desirable should be given to a virtuous person.

original: ata eva khalo doṣān sādhubhyaḥ saṃprayacchati // / //
analyzed: atas eva khalaḥ doṣān sādhubhyaḥ saṃprayacchati
translated: For this very reason, a scoundrel bestows faults upon the virtuous.

original: karuṇādravam eva durjanaḥ sutarāṃ satpuruṣaṃ prabādhate /
analyzed: karuṇā dravam eva durjanaḥ sutarām sat puruṣam prabādhate
translated: A scoundrel is all the more cruel to a good man, being full of compassion.

original: mṛdukaṃ hi bhinatti kaṇṭakaḥ kaṭhine kuṇṭhaka iva jāyate // / //
analyzed: mṛdukam hi bhinatti kaṇṭakaḥ kaṭhine kuṇṭhakaḥ iva jāyate
translated: For a thorn pierces what is soft, but on a hard surface it is blunted.

original: ārambhagurvī kṣayiṇī krameṇa laghvī purā vṛddhimatī ca paścāt /
analyzed: ārambha gurvī kṣayiṇī krameṇa laghvī purā vṛddhimatī ca paścāt
translated: Heavy in the beginning, gradually decreasing, light later, having first increased,

original: dinasya pūrvārdhaparārdhabhinnā chāyeva maitrī khalasajjanānām // / //
analyzed: dinasya pūrva ardha para ardha bhinnā chāyā iva maitrī khala sat janānām
translated: Like a shadow divided into the first and last parts of the day, the friendship of the wicked and the good is different.

original: khalānāṃ kharjūrakṣitiruhakaṭhoraṃ kva ca manaḥ kva conmīlanmallīkusumasukumārāḥ kavigiraḥ /
analyzed: khalānām kharjūra kṣitiruha kaṭhoram kva ca manaḥ kva ca unmīlat mallī kusuma su kumārāḥ kavi giraḥ
translated: Where is the mind of the wicked, hard as a date palm tree, and where are the tender words of a poet, delicate as jasmine flowers in bloom?

original: itīmaṃ vyāmohaṃ parihara vicitrāḥ śṛṇu kathā yathāyaṃ pīyūṣadyutir upalakhaṇḍaṃ dravayati // / //
analyzed: iti imam vyāmoham parihara vicitrāḥ śṛṇu kathāḥ yathā ayam pīyūṣa dyutiḥ upala khaṇḍam dravayati  /
translated: Therefore, avoid this confusion and listen to various stories, as this moon-like nectar melts a piece of stone.

original: upakāriṇi śuddhamatau vārjane yaḥ samācarati pāpam /
analyzed: upakāriṇi śuddha matau vā arjane yaḥ samācarati pāpam
translated: He who commits sin against a benefactor, a pure-minded one, or a guest,

original: taṃ janam asatyasaṃdhaṃ bhagavati vasudhe kathaṃ vahasi // / //🔽mukhe nīcasya patitā aher iva payaḥkaṇāḥ /
analyzed: tam janam asatya saṃdham bhagavati vasudhe katham vahasi  / mukhe nīcasya patitāḥ aheḥ iva payaḥ kaṇāḥ
translated: how can you, O blessed Earth, bear that man who is false to his promises?🔽The drops of milk that fall into the mouth of a low person,

original: kṣaṇena viṣatāṃ yānti sūktapīyūṣabindavaḥ // / //
analyzed: kṣaṇena viṣa tām yānti sūkta pīyūṣa bindavaḥ
translated: like those into the mouth of a snake, become poison in a moment, even though they are sweet and nectar-like.

original: muṇḍāpriyād āyatiduḥkhadāyino vasantam utsārya vijṛmbhitaśriyaḥ /
analyzed: muṇḍa apriyāt āyati duḥkha dāyinaḥ vasantam utsārya vijṛmbhita śriyaḥ
translated: Having driven away the spring, which brings future sorrow to the beloved, and whose glory is displayed,

original: na kaḥ khalāt tāpitamitramaṇḍalād upaiti pāpaṃ tapavāsarād iva // / //
analyzed: na kaḥ khalāt tāpita mitra maṇḍalāt upaiti pāpam tapa vāsarāt iva
translated: who does not obtain sin from the wicked, as from a day of penance, which brings a circle of heated friends?

original: naradattasya
analyzed: naradattasya
translated: Of Naradatta

original: tulyotpattī prakṛtidhavalāv apy amū śaṅkhasomau tatra sthāṇur vidhum asadṛśenottamāṅgena dhatte /
analyzed: tulya utpattī prakṛti dhavalau api amū śaṅkha somau tatra sthāṇuḥ vidhum asadṛśena uttamāṅgena dhatte
translated: Although born equally, these two, the conch and the moon, are naturally white, there the post holds the moon with an unequal head.

original: śaṅkhas tāpakrakacanicayair bhidyate śaṅkhakāraiḥ ko nāmāntaḥprakṛtikuṭilo durgatiṃ nābhiyāti // / //
analyzed: śaṅkhaḥ tāpa krakaca nicayaiḥ bhidyate śaṅkhakāraiḥ kaḥ nāma antar prakṛti kuṭilaḥ durgatim nā abhiyāti  /
translated: The conch is pierced by conch-makers with a multitude of saws that torment, who, indeed, who is not crooked within, does not approach misfortune?

original: akalitanijapararūpaḥ svakam api doṣaṃ parasthitaṃ vetti /
analyzed: a kalita nija para rūpaḥ svakam api doṣam para sthitam vetti
translated: Not distinguishing his own and others' forms, he knows even his own faults as existing in others.

original: nāvāsthitas taṭasthān acalān api vicalitān manute // / //
analyzed: na avāsthitaḥ taṭa sthān acalān api vicalitān manute  /
translated: Seated in a boat, he thinks even the immovable ones on the shore to be moving.

original: āśrayāśaḥ kṛṣṇavartmā dahanaś caiṣa durjanaḥ /
analyzed: āśraya āśaḥ kṛṣṇavartmā dahanaḥ ca eṣa durjanaḥ
translated: This wicked person is the abode of evil, the black path, and the fire.

original: agnir eva tathāpy asmin syād bhasmani hutaṃ hutam // / //
analyzed: agniḥ eva tathā api asmin syāt bhasmani hutam hutam  /
translated: Even so, in him, the oblation offered in the ashes would be truly offered.

original: varam ākṣīṇataivāstu śaśino durjanasya ca /
analyzed: varam ākṣīṇa tā evā astu śaśinaḥ durjanasya ca
translated: Better to be without decrease for the moon and the wicked person.

original: na pravṛddhis tu vistāri lāñchanapratipādinī // / //
analyzed: na pravṛddhiḥ tu vistāri lāñchana pratipādinī
translated: But not the increase that leads to the spread of disgrace.

original: sarvatra mukharacapalāḥ prabhavanti na lokasaṃmatā guṇinaḥ /
analyzed: sarvatra mukhara capalāḥ prabhavanti na loka saṃmatāḥ guṇinaḥ
translated: Everywhere the talkative and fickle ones prevail, not the virtuous who are respected by the people.

original: tiṣṭhanti vārirāśeḥur upari taraṅgās tale maṇayaḥ // / //
analyzed: tiṣṭhanti upari taraṅgāḥ tale maṇayaḥ
translated: The waves remain on the surface of the ocean, the jewels remain at the bottom.

original: ārambharamaṇīyāni vimarde virasāni ca /
analyzed: ārambha ramaṇīyāni vimarde virasāni ca
translated: The beginnings are delightful, but in the end they are tasteless.

original: prāyo vairāvasānāni saṃgatāni khalaiḥ saha // / //🔽guṇakaṇikān api sujanaḥ śaśilekhām iva śivaḥ śirasi kurute /
analyzed: prāyas vaira avasānāni saṃgatāni khalaiḥ saha  guṇa kaṇikān api su janaḥ śaśi lekhām iva śivaḥ śirasi kurute
translated: Usually the associations with the wicked end in enmity.🔽The virtuous person places even the smallest virtues on his head, like the moon.

original: candra iva padmalakṣmīṃ na kṣamate paraguṇaṃ piśunaḥ // / //
analyzed: candraḥ iva padma lakṣmīm na kṣamate para guṇam piśunaḥ
translated: The slanderer cannot bear the virtues of others, like the moon cannot bear the beauty of the lotus.

original: bibhīmo vayam atyantaṃ cākrikasya guṇād api /
analyzed: bibhīmaḥ vayam atyantam cākrikasya guṇāt api
translated: We are extremely afraid of the virtuous even from the sound of the wheel.

original: niṣpannam api yaḥ pātraṃ guṇenaiva nikṛntati // / //
analyzed: niṣpannam api yaḥ pātram guṇena eva nikṛntati
translated: He who cuts down even a completed vessel by its virtue.

original: parasaṃtāpanahetur yatrāhani na prayāti niṣpattim /
analyzed: para saṃtāpana hetuḥ yatra ahani na prayāti niṣpattim
translated: Where the cause of tormenting others does not come to completion even during the day,

original: antarmanā asādhur gaṇayati na tadāyuṣo madhye // / //
analyzed: antarmanāḥ asādhuḥ gaṇayati na tat āyuṣaḥ madhye
translated: The wicked man, with a troubled mind, does not reckon that in the middle of his life.

original: divasān tān abhinandati bahumanute teṣu janmano lābham /
analyzed: divasān tān abhinandati bahu manute teṣu janmanaḥ lābham
translated: He rejoices in those days and values the gain of life in them,

original: ye yānti duṣṭabuddheḥ paropatāpābhiyogena // / //
analyzed: ye yānti duṣṭa buddheḥ para upatāpa abhiyogena
translated: Which pass by due to the exertion of harming others with a wicked mind.

original: dayāmṛduṣu durjanaḥ paṭutarāvalepoddhavaḥ parāṃ vrajati vikriyāṃ na hi bhayaṃ tataḥ paśyati /
analyzed: dayā mṛduṣu durjanaḥ paṭutara avalepa uddhavaḥ parām vrajati vikriyām na hi bhayam tatas paśyati
translated: The wicked man, in those who are tender with compassion, becomes more insolent and goes to the highest degree of change, for he does not see fear from them.

original: yatas tu bhayaśaṅkayā sukṛśayāpi saṃspṛśyate vinīta iva nīcakaiś carati tatra śāntoddhavaḥ // / //
analyzed: yatas tu bhaya śaṅkayā su kṛśayā api saṃspṛśyate vinītaḥ iva nīcakaiḥ carati tatra śānta uddhavaḥ
translated: But from where he is touched even by a very slight suspicion of fear, he moves there with a subdued mind, with a very low voice, like a humble person.

original: śūrasya
analyzed: śūrasya
translated: Of the hero

original: asajjanāś cen madhurair vacobhiḥ śakyanta eva pratikartum āryaiḥ /
analyzed: asat janāḥ ced madhuraiḥ vacobhiḥ śakyante eva pratikartum āryaiḥ
translated: If the noble ones can be repaid with sweet words by the wicked,

original: tat ketakīreṇubhir amburāśer bandhakriyāyām api kaḥ prayāsaḥ // / //
analyzed: tat ketakī reṇubhiḥ amburāśeḥ bandha kriyāyām api kaḥ prayāsaḥ
translated: What effort is there even in the act of binding the ocean with ketaki pollen?

original: nūnaṃ darpāt tuhinarucinā durjanasya pramārṣṭuṃ nītaṃ ceto na ca dhavalitaṃ helayā nārpitaṃ ca /
analyzed: nūnam darpāt tuhinarucinā durjanasya pramārṣṭum nītam cetaḥ na ca dhavalitam helayā nā arpitam ca
translated: Surely, the moon, out of pride, has wiped away the mind of the wicked, but has not playfully given it a white color,

original: yenedānīṃ malinahṛdayo lakṣyate śītaraśmir yasmāc cāyaṃ hṛdayarahito durvidhaḥ sarvadaiva // / //
analyzed: yena idānīm malina hṛdayaḥ lakṣyate śītaraśmiḥ yasmāt ca ayam hṛdaya rahitaḥ durvidhaḥ sarvadā eva
translated: By which the moon is now seen to have a defiled heart, and this wicked one is always devoid of a heart, for this very reason.

original: niryantraṇaṃ yatra na vartitavyaṃ na moditavyaṃ praṇayātivāde /
analyzed: niryantraṇam yatra na vartitavyam na moditavyam praṇaya ativāde
translated: Where one should not act without restraint, nor rejoice in excessive flattery out of affection,

original: viśaṅkitānyonyabhayaṃ sudūrān namaskriyām arhati sauhṛdaṃ tat // / //
analyzed: viśaṅkita anyonya bhayam su dūrāt namaskriyām arhati sauhṛdam tat
translated: That friendship deserves to be saluted from a distance, fearing mutual suspicion and danger.

original: abhinandasya
analyzed: abhinandasya
translated: Of Abhinanda

original: ete snigdhatamā iti mā mā kṣudreṣu kuruta viśvāsam /
analyzed: ete snigdhatamāḥ iti mā mā kṣudreṣu kuruta viśvāsam
translated: Do not, do not place your trust in these most intimate ones, in the petty ones.

original: siddhārthānām eṣāṃ sneho 'py aśrūṇi pātayati // / //
analyzed: siddhārthānām eṣām snehaḥ u pi aśrūṇi pātayati
translated: Even their affection, when their aims are accomplished, makes tears fall.

original: vṛthājvalitakopāgneḥ paruṣākṣaravādinaḥ /
analyzed: vṛthā jvalita kopa agneḥ paruṣa akṣara vādinaḥ
translated: For a wicked man who needlessly kindles the fire of anger and speaks harsh words,

original: durjanasyāuṣadhaṃ nāsti kiṃcid anyad anuttarāt // / //
analyzed: durjanasya auṣadham na asti kiṃcid anyat anuttarāt
translated: There is no remedy other than the highest, for one who is wicked.

original: cakrasaṃbhāriṇi krūre paracchidrānusāriṇi /
analyzed: cakra saṃbhāriṇi krūre para chidra anusāriṇi
translated: For one who bears a wheel and a mace, who is cruel, who follows others' weaknesses,

original: dvijihve dṛṣṭamātre cet kasya na syāc camatkṛtiḥ // / //
analyzed: dvi jihve dṛṣṭa mātre ced kasya na syāt camatkṛtiḥ
translated: Who has two tongues, if one is amazed merely by seeing him, who would not be?

original: cakṣur āśrayate kāmaḥ kāmukasya daridrataḥ /
analyzed: cakṣuḥ āśrayate kāmaḥ kāmukasya daridrataḥ
translated: Desire resorts to the eye of a passionate man out of poverty,

original: krūrasya cāprabhavataḥ paradrohaḥ sarasvatīm // / //
analyzed: krūrasya ca aprabhavataḥ paradrohaḥ sarasvatīm
translated: And the harsh speech of a cruel man, unable to rise up, resorts to the goddess of speech.

original: śatānandasya
analyzed: śatānandasya
translated: Of Shatananda

original: khalaṃ dṛṣṭvaiva sādhūnāṃ hṛdayaṃ kāṣṭhavad bhavet /
analyzed: khalam dṛṣṭvā eva sādhūnām hṛdayam kāṣṭha vat bhavet
translated: The heart of the good becomes like wood merely by seeing a wicked man,

original: tatas tad dārayaty asya vācaḥ krakacakarkaśāḥ // / //
analyzed: tatas tat dārayati asya vācaḥ krakaca karkaśāḥ
translated: Then his words, harsh like a saw, break it.

original: hetor vinopakārī yadi nāma śateṣu kaścid ekaḥ syāt /
analyzed: hetoḥ vinā upakārī yadi nāma śateṣu kaścid ekaḥ syāt
translated: If by chance there were even one helpful person among a hundred for a reason,

original: tatrāpi kliṣṭadhiyāṃ doṣaṃ vakṣyaty atikhalatvam // / //
analyzed: tatra api kliṣṭa dhiyām doṣam vakṣyati ati khala tvam
translated: Even there, he will speak of the fault of the defiled-minded, of extreme wickedness.

original: ākrānteva mahopalena muninā śapteva durvāsasā sātatyaṃ bata mudriteva jatunā nīteva mūrchāṃ viṣaiḥ /
analyzed: ākrāntā iva mahopalena muninā śaptā iva durvāsasā sātatyam bata mudritā iva jatunā nītā iva mūrchām viṣaiḥ
translated: As if crushed by a great rock, as if cursed by the sage Durvāsas, as if constantly sealed with lac, as if rendered unconscious by poison,

original: baddhevātanurajjubhiḥ paraguṇān vaktuṃ na śaktā satī jihvā lohaśalākayā khalamukhe viddheva saṃlakṣyate // / //
analyzed: baddhā iva a tanu rajjubhiḥ para guṇān vaktum na śaktā satī jihvā loha śalākayā khala mukhe viddhā iva saṃlakṣyate  /
translated: As if bound with thin ropes, being unable to speak of the good qualities of others, the tongue is seen as if pierced with an iron needle in the mouth of a wicked person.

original: śrīdharmadāsasya
analyzed: śrī dharmadāsasya
translated: Of Śrī Dharma Dāsa

original: prakṛtir iha khalānāṃ doṣacittaṃ guṇajñe vinayalalitabhāve dveṣaraktā ca buddhiḥ /
analyzed: prakṛtiḥ iha khalānām doṣa cittam guṇa jñe vinaya lalita bhāve dveṣa raktā ca buddhiḥ
translated: The nature of the wicked here is a mind full of faults towards the virtuous, and an intellect tainted with hatred towards one who is humble and charming.

original: ubhayam idam avaśyaṃ jāyate sarvavāraṃ paṭur api niyatātmā kīrtim evābhidhatte // / //
analyzed: ubhayam idam avaśyam jāyate sarva vāram paṭuḥ api niyata ātmā kīrtim eva abhidhatte
translated: Both of these always arise, but even the sharp-witted one who has self-control speaks only of fame.

original: ity asadvrajyā ////
analyzed: iti asat vrajyā
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the wicked.

original: tato dīnavrajyā
analyzed: tatas dīna vrajyā
translated: Then begins the chapter on the wretched.

original: prātar bāṣpāmbubinduvyatikaravigalatklinnasṛkkaḥ kathaṃcit kiṃcit saṃkubjajaṅghājanitajaḍajavo jīrṇajānur jarārtaḥ /
analyzed: prātar bāṣpa ambu bindu vyatikara vigalat klinna sṛkkaḥ kathaṃcid kiṃcid saṃkubja jaṅghā janita jaḍa javaḥ jīrṇa jānuḥ jarā ārtaḥ
translated: In the morning, somehow, with tears and drops of water dripping from his mouth, with his legs bent and slow due to old age, with his knees worn out, afflicted by old age,

original: muṣṭyāvaṣṭabhya yaṣṭiṃ kaṭipuṭavicaṭatkarpaṭaḥ pluṣṭakanthaḥ kunthann utthāya pānthaḥ pathi paruṣamarunmūrcchyamānaḥ prayāti // /🔽puṇyānau pūrṇavāñchaḥ prathamam agaṇitaploṣadoṣaḥ pradoṣe pānthas taptvā prasuptaḥ pratatatanutṛṇe dhāmani grāmadevyāḥ /
analyzed: muṣṭyā avaṣṭabhya yaṣṭim kaṭi puṭa vicaṭat karpaṭaḥ pluṣṭa kanthaḥ kunthan utthāya pānthaḥ pathi paruṣa marut mūrcchyamānaḥ prayāti  / puṇya anau pūrṇa vāñchaḥ prathamam agaṇita ploṣa doṣaḥ pradoṣe pānthaḥ taptvā prasuptaḥ pratata tanu tṛṇe dhāmani grāmadevyāḥ
translated: The traveler, having risen with difficulty, holding the stick with his fist, his patched garment torn at the hip, his throat parched, proceeds on the road, fainting in the harsh wind.🔽The traveler, his desires fulfilled, not counting the hardship of the cold, having suffered in the evening, sleeps on the ground of the village goddess, spread with thin grass.

original: utkampī karpaṭārghe jarati padahaticchidrite cchinnanidro vāte vāti prakamaṃ himakaṇini kaṇan koṇataḥ koṇam eti // / 🔽bāṇasya Svsu /ā / /
analyzed: utkampī karpaṭa arghe jarati pada hati chidrite chinna nidraḥ vāte vāti prakamam hima kaṇini kaṇan koṇatas koṇam eti  / bāṇasya su su ā
translated: Shivering, in a tattered garment, his sleep broken by the holes in the floor, when the wind blows strongly with icy particles, he goes from corner to corner.🔽Of Bāṇa.🔽Of Śpāṇḍā.🔽Of Svaśva.

original: Spdśā /pa / /
analyzed: sp śāpa
translated: Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.

original: Smvsū /mu / / / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: skmsauka
translated: Of Svaśva.

original: potān etān api gṛhavati grīṣmamāsāvasānaṃ yāvan nirvāhayati bhavatī yena vā kenacid vā /
analyzed: potān etān api gṛhavati grīṣma māsa avasānam yāvat nirvāhayati bhavatī yena vā kenacid vā
translated: Of Sūtra.

original: paścād ambhodharajalaparīpātam āsādya tumbī kūṣmāṇḍī ca prabhavati tadā bhūbhujaḥ ke vayaṃ ke // / //
analyzed: paścāt ambhodhara jala parīpātam āsādya tumbī kūṣmāṇḍī ca prabhavati tadā bhūbhujaḥ ke vayam ke
translated: Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.🔽Of Sūtra.🔽Of Mu.🔽Of Svaśva.

original: dharaṇīdharasya
analyzed: dharaṇīdharasya
translated: Of Sūtra.

original: kṣutkṣāmāḥ śiśavaḥ śavā iva tanur mandādaro bāndhavo liptā jarjarakarkarījalalavair no māṃ tathā bādhate /
analyzed: kṣudh kṣāmāḥ śiśavaḥ śavāḥ iva tanuḥ manda ādaraḥ bāndhavaḥ liptā jarjara karkarī jala lavaiḥ no mām tathā bādhate
translated: The children are emaciated with hunger, my body is like a corpse, my relatives are indifferent, and I am smeared with the drops of water from a leaky pot - this does not trouble me so much.

original: gehinyāḥ sphuṭitāṃśukaṃ ghaṭayituṃ kṛtvā sakākusmitaṃ kupyantī prativeśinī pratidinaṃ sūcīṃ yathā yācitā // / //
analyzed: gehinyāḥ sphuṭita aṃśukam ghaṭayitum kṛtvā sa kākusmitam kupyantī prativeśinī pratidinam sūcīm yathā yācitā  /
translated: But the neighbor, who was asked every day to lend a needle, with a feigned smile, when the wife's torn garment was to be mended, became angry - (the rest is lost).

original: kasyacit / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: kasyacid
translated: Of someone.

original: sākrandāḥ śiśavaḥ sapatrapuṭakā vaptuḥ purovartinaḥ pracchanne ca vadhūr vibhāgakuśalā madhye sthitā gehinī /
analyzed: sa ākrandāḥ śiśavaḥ sa patra puṭakāḥ vaptuḥ purovartinaḥ pracchanne ca vadhūḥ vibhāga kuśalā madhye sthitā gehinī
translated: The crying children with their leaf-cups in front of the farmer, the wife hidden, the housewife skilled in distribution standing in the middle,

original: kaṭyācchādanabandhakena katham apy āsāditenāndhasā sindūrāruṇamaṇḍale savitari prāṇāhutir dīyate // / //
analyzed: kaṭyā ācchādana bandhakena katham api āsāditena andhasā sindūra aruṇa maṇḍale savitari prāṇa āhutiḥ dīyate  /  /
translated: with difficulty obtaining the barley-meal, the covering for the hips, the sun-red orb, the life-oblation is offered to the sun.

original: ete daridraśiśavas tanujīrṇakanthāṃ skandhe nidhāya malināṃ pulakākulāṅgāḥ /
analyzed: ete daridra śiśavaḥ tanu jīrṇa kanthām skandhe nidhāya malinām pulaka ākula aṅgāḥ
translated: These poor children, placing on their shoulders a dirty, worn-out blanket, their bodies covered with goosebumps,

original: sūryasphuratkarakarambitabhittideśa lābhāya śītasamaye kalim ācaranti // / //
analyzed: sūrya sphurat kara karambita bhitti deśa lābhāya śīta samaye kalim ācaranti
translated: in the cold season, they quarrel to obtain a place on the wall warmed by the sun's rays.

original: tasminn eva gṛhodare rasavatī tatraiva sā kaṇḍanī tatropaskaraṇāni tatra śiśavas tatraiva vāsaḥ svayam /
analyzed: tasmin eva gṛha udare rasavatī tatra eva sā kaṇḍanī tatra upaskaraṇāni tatra śiśavaḥ tatra eva vāsaḥ svayam
translated: In that very house is the tasty food, there is the mortar, there are the utensils, there are the children, there is the cloth for myself.

original: etat soḍhavato 'pi duḥsthagṛhiṇaḥ kiṃ brūmahe durdaśām adya śvo vijaniṣyamāṇagṛhiṇī tatraiva yat kunthati // / //
analyzed: etat duḥstha gṛhiṇaḥ kim brūmahe durdaśām adya śvas vijaniṣyamāṇa gṛhiṇī tatra eva yat kunthati  /
translated: What shall we say of the miserable condition of the unfortunate householder who has to bear all this? The wife of the poor householder, who will give birth tomorrow, limps there in the same house today, thinking of the same things.🔽Of someone.

original: kasyacit / Skmsa /u /ka / /🔽vainateyasya
analyzed: kasyacid  vainateyasya
translated: Of Garuḍa.

original: adyāśanaṃ śiśujanasya balena jātaṃ śvo vā kathaṃ nu bhaviteti vicintayantī /
analyzed: adyā aśanam śiśu janasya balena jātam śvas vā katham nu bhavitā iti vicintayantī
translated: Thinking, Today's meal was made possible by the strength of the children. How will it be tomorrow?

original: ity aśrupātamalinīkṛtagaṇḍadeśā necched daridragṛhiṇī rajanīvirāmam // / //
analyzed: iti aśru pāta malinīkṛta gaṇḍa deśā na icchet daridra gṛhiṇī rajanī virāmam
translated: The poor housewife, with her cheeks soiled by the falling of tears, does not wish for the end of the night.

original: kasyacit / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: kasyacid
translated: Of someone.

original: saktūñ śocati saṃplutān pratikaroty ākrandato bālakān pratyutsiñcati karpareṇa salilaṃ śayyātṛṇaṃ rakṣati /
analyzed: saktūm śocati saṃplutān pratikaroti ākrandataḥ bālakān pratyutsiñcati karpareṇa salilam śayyā tṛṇam rakṣati
translated: She grieves over the scattered barley, she attends to the crying children, she sprinkles water with a winnowing basket, she protects the bedding straw.

original: dattvā mūrdhani śīrṇaṃ śūrpaśakalaṃ jīrṇe gṛhe vyākulā kiṃ tad yan na karoti duḥsthagṛhiṇī deve bhṛśaṃ varṣati // / //
analyzed: dattvā mūrdhani śīrṇam śūrpa śakalam jīrṇe gṛhe vyākulā kim tat yat na karoti duḥstha gṛhiṇī deve bhṛśam varṣati  /
translated: Having placed on her head the broken pieces of the winnowing basket, she is distressed in the old house. What is that which the unfortunate housewife does not do when the god rains heavily?

original: yogeśvarasya /
analyzed: yogeśvarasya
translated: Of Yogeśvara.

original: Skmsa /u /ka / / laṅgadattasya / Svsu /ā /
analyzed: laṅgadattasya svsuā
translated: Skm-su-u-ka. Of Langadatta.

original: jaradambarasaṃvaraṇagranthividhau granthakāra eko 'ham /
analyzed: jarat ambara saṃvaraṇa granthi vidhau granthakāraḥ ekaḥ ham
translated: I am the only author in the knotting of the garment covering the old sky.

original: parimitakadannabaṇṭanavidyāpāraṃgatā gṛhiṇī // / //
analyzed: parimita kadanna baṇṭana vidyā pāraṃgatā gṛhiṇī
translated: The housewife is skilled in the art of distributing limited food and vegetables.

original: vīrasya / Skmsa /u /ka / / bhānoḥ
analyzed: vīrasya skmsauka bhānoḥ
translated: Of the hero. Skm-su-u-ka. Of Bhanu.

original: mā rodīś ciram ehi vatsa viphalaṃ dṛṣṭvādya putrān imān āyāto bhavato 'pi dāsyati pitā graiveyakaṃ vāsasī /
analyzed: mā rodīḥ ciram ehi vatsa viphalam dṛṣṭvā adya putrān imān āyātaḥ dāsyati pitā graiveyakam vāsasī
translated: Do not weep for long, come, dear child, seeing these sons of yours fruitless today, your father will also give you a necklace and garments.

original: śrutvaivaṃ gṛhiṇīvacāṃsi nikaṭe kuḍyasya niṣkiṃcano niśvasyāśrujalaphutānatamukhaḥ pānthaḥ punaḥ proṣitaḥ // / //
analyzed: śrutvā evam gṛhiṇī vacāṃsi nikaṭe kuḍyasya niṣkiṃcanaḥ niśvasya aśru jala phuta ānata mukhaḥ pānthaḥ punar proṣitaḥ  /
translated: Hearing these words of the housewife, the penniless traveler, sighing with his face lowered and eyes filled with tears, has left again, near the wall.

original: kūṣmāṇḍīviṭapaḥ phalaty avirataṃ siktaḥ suvarṇāmbunā bhūyobhir gaditaṃ hitaiṣibhir itīvāsmābhir aṅgīkṛtam /
analyzed: kūṣmāṇḍī viṭapaḥ phalati aviratam siktaḥ suvarṇa ambunā bhūyobhiḥ gaditam hita eṣibhiḥ iti iva asmābhiḥ aṅgīkṛtam
translated: The pumpkin vine bears fruit incessantly, watered with golden water, as if we have accepted it, spoken by the well-wishers again and again.

original: tat saṃyācya kutaścid īśvaragṛhād ānīyamānaṃ śanaiḥ adhvany eva hi bindubhir vigalitaṃ śrāṇe śarāvodare // / //
analyzed: tat saṃyācya kutaścid īśvara gṛhāt ānīyamānam śanais adhvani eva hi bindubhiḥ vigalitam śrāṇe śarāva udare  /
translated: Having begged it from somewhere, the lord's house, and brought it slowly, on the road itself, the drops have fallen into the pot in the bowl.

original: mātar dharmapare dayāṃ kuru mayi śrānte ca vaideśike dvārālindakakoṇakeṣu nibhṛtaṃ sthitvā kṣipāmi kṣapām /
analyzed: mātar dharma pare dayām kuru mayi śrānte ca vaideśike dvāra alindaka koṇakeṣu nibhṛtam sthitvā kṣipāmi kṣapām
translated: Mother, devoted to dharma, have mercy on me, a weary traveler. I will spend the night stealthily in a corner of the porch.

original: ity evaṃ gṛhiṇīpracaṇḍavadanāvākyena nirbhartsito hastanyastapalālamuṣṭivibhavaḥ pānthaḥ śanair gacchati // / //
analyzed: iti evam gṛhiṇī pracaṇḍa vadanā vākyena nirbhartsitaḥ hasta nyasta palāla muṣṭi vibhavaḥ pānthaḥ śanais gacchati  /
translated: Thus rebuked by the harsh words of the housewife, the traveler, his wealth reduced to a handful of straw in his hand, goes away slowly.

original: kasyacit Svsu /ā / /🔽ant spd śā /pa / ravidattasya /
analyzed: kasyacid su su  an t sp śāpa ravidattasya
translated: Of someone.🔽Of Ravi Datta.

original: Smvsū /mu / / raviguptasya /
analyzed: ravi guptasya
translated: Of Ravi Gupta.

original: Skmsa /u /ka / śatānandasya
analyzed: śatānandasya
translated: Of Shatananda.

original: lagnaḥ śṛṅgayuge gṛhī satanayo vṛddhau gurū pārśvayoḥ pucchāgre gṛhiṇī khureṣu śiśavo lagnā vadhūḥ kambale /
analyzed: lagnaḥ śṛṅga yuge gṛhī sa tanayaḥ vṛddhau gurū pārśvayoḥ puccha agre gṛhiṇī khureṣu śiśavaḥ lagnā vadhūḥ kambale
translated: The bull is caught between the horns, the old cow and calf are in the flanks, the wife is in the tip of the tail, and the young calves are caught in the hooves. The young bride is caught in the blanket.

original: ekaḥ śīrṇajaradgavo vidhivaśāt sarvasvabhūto gṛhe sarveṇaiva kuṭumbakena rudatā suptaḥ samutthāpyate // / //
analyzed: ekaḥ śīrṇa jaradgavaḥ vidhi vaśāt sarva sva bhūtaḥ gṛhe sarveṇa eva kuṭumbakena rudatā suptaḥ samutthāpyate
translated: The old bull, the only remaining wealth in the house, is asleep, having been woken up by the whole crying family.

original: kasyacit / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: kasyacid
translated: Of someone.

original: śītavātasamudbhinna pulakāṅkuraśālinī /
analyzed: śīta vāta samudbhinna pulaka aṅkura śālinī
translated: Covered with goosebumps arising from the cold wind,

original: mamāmbaravihīnasya tvag eva paṭikāyate // / //
analyzed: mama ambara vihīnasya tvac eva paṭikāyate
translated: my skin itself seems to be a cloth, as I am without clothes.

original: sadyo vibhidyate nūnaṃ daridratanupañjaram /
analyzed: sadyas vibhidyate nūnam daridra tanu pañjaram
translated: The cage of the poor body is surely torn apart immediately.

original: yadi na syān manorājya rajjubhir dṛḍhasaṃyatam // / //🔽prāyo daridraśiśavaḥ paramandirāṇāṃ dvāreṣu dattakarapallavalīnadehāḥ /
analyzed: yadi na syāt manorājya rajjubhiḥ dṛḍha saṃyatam  prāyas daridra śiśavaḥ para mandirāṇām dvāreṣu datta kara pallava līna dehāḥ
translated: If the kingdom of the mind were not firmly restrained by the ropes of self-control,🔽Alas! The poor children, their bodies clinging to the doors of the great houses, their words of request hidden in shame,

original: lajjānigūḍhavacaso bata bhoktukāmā bhoktāram ardhanayanena vilokayanti // / //
analyzed: lajjā nigūḍha vacasaḥ bata bhoktu kāmāḥ bhoktāram ardha nayanena vilokayanti  /
translated: Do indeed look at the giver with half an eye, desiring to eat.

original: kasyacit / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: kasyacid
translated: Of someone.

original: adhvaśramāya caraṇau virahāya dārā abhyarthanāya vacanaṃ ca vapur jarāyai /
analyzed: adhva śramāya caraṇau virahāya dārāḥ abhyarthanāya vacanam ca vapuḥ jarāyai
translated: My feet for the fatigue of the journey, my wife for separation, my words for requesting, and my body for old age,

original: etāni me vidadhatas tava sarvadaiva dhātas trapā yadi na kiṃ na pariśramo 'pi // / //
analyzed: etāni me vidadhataḥ tava sarvadā eva dhātar trapā yadi na kim na
translated: O Creator, while I am thus engaged, if you feel shame, then why not also feel fatigue?

original: vardhanamukhāsikāyām udarapiśācaḥ kim icchakām icchan /
analyzed: vardhana mukha asikāyām udara piśācaḥ kim icchakām icchan
translated: In the mouth of a beggar, a stomach-demon, desiring to desire,

original: paryākulayati gṛhiṇīm akiṃcanaḥ kṛpaṇasaṃvāsaḥ // / //
analyzed: paryākulayati gṛhiṇīm akiṃcanaḥ kṛpaṇa saṃvāsaḥ
translated: The association with a miser, being penniless, disturbs the housewife.

original: varaṃ mṛto na tu kṣudras tathāpi mahad antaram /
analyzed: varam mṛtaḥ na tu kṣudraḥ tathā api mahat antaram
translated: Better to die than to be a petty man, but still there is a great difference.

original: ekasya bandhuḥnr nādatte nāmāny asyākhilo janaḥ // / //🔽kṛpaṇasyāstu dāridryaṃ kārpaṇyāvṛtikārakam /
analyzed: ekasya na ādatte nāmāni asya akhilaḥ janaḥ     kṛpaṇasya astu dāridryam kārpaṇya āvṛti kārakam
translated: The kinsmen of one do not take his name, all other people do.🔽Let the miser have poverty, which causes concealment by meanness,

original: vibhavas tasya taddoṣa ghoṣaṇāpaṭuḍiṇḍimaḥ // / //
analyzed: vibhavaḥ tasya tad doṣa ghoṣaṇā paṭu ḍiṇḍimaḥ
translated: His wealth is the loud drum that proclaims that fault.

original: vyāsasya
analyzed: vyāsasya
translated: Of Vyasa

original: jīvatāpi śavenāpi kṛpaṇena na dīyate /
analyzed: jīvatā api śavena api kṛpaṇena na dīyate
translated: Even when alive, even when dead, even when miserable, flesh is not given.

original: māṃsaṃ vardhayatānena kākasyopakṛtiḥ kṛtā // / //
analyzed: māṃsam vardhayata anena kākasya upakṛtiḥ kṛtā
translated: By this one who is increasing his flesh, a favor has been done to the crow.

original: kavirājasya
analyzed: kavirājasya
translated: Of Kavirāja

original: śrīphalaṃ yan na tad dīrgham iti tāvad vyavasthitam /
analyzed: śrīphalam yat na tat dīrgham iti tāvat vyavasthitam
translated: That the Bilva fruit is not long - this much is established.

original: tatraikāntadhṛtir yasya manyate mugdha eva saḥ // / //
analyzed: tatra ekānta dhṛtiḥ yasya manyate mugdhaḥ eva saḥ
translated: He who has absolute faith in it is indeed foolish.

original: risūkasya 🔽dṛḍhataranibaddhamuṣṭeḥ koṣaniṣaṇṇasya sahajamalinasya /
analyzed: risūkasya  dṛḍhatara nibaddha muṣṭeḥ koṣa niṣaṇṇasya sahaja malinasya
translated: Of Risūka🔽Of the sword, which is tightly clenched in the fist, kept in the scabbard, naturally dirty,

original: kṛpaṇasya kṛpāṇasya ca kevalam ākārato bhedaḥ // / //
analyzed: kṛpaṇasya kṛpāṇasya ca kevalam ākārataḥ bhedaḥ
translated: and miserly, only the appearance is different.

original: gobhaṭṭasya
analyzed: go bhaṭṭasya
translated: Of Gobhaṭṭa

original: pathika he vijahīhi vṛthārthitāṃ na khalu vetsi navas tvam ihāgataḥ /
analyzed: pathika he vijahīhi vṛthā arthi tām na khalu vetsi navaḥ tvam iha āgataḥ
translated: O traveler, give up this useless begging. You do not know that you have come here as a newcomer.

original: idam ahibhramitaṃ pacamandiraṃ balibhujo 'pi na yānti yadantikam // / //
analyzed: idam ahi bhramitam paca mandiram balibhujaḥ na yānti yad antikam
translated: This is the house of the serpent's churning, even the vultures do not go near it.

original: raver astamaye yena nidrā netreṣu nirmitā /
analyzed: raveḥ astamaye yena nidrā netreṣu nirmitā
translated: By whom sleep was created in the eyes at sunset,

original: tena kiṃ na kṛto mṛtyur martyānāṃ vibhavakṣaye // / //
analyzed: tena kim na kṛtaḥ mṛtyuḥ martyānām vibhava kṣaye
translated: why was death not created by him at the end of mortals' wealth?

original: yenaivāmbarakhaṇḍena divā sañcarate raviḥ /
analyzed: yena eva ambara khaṇḍena divā sañcarate raviḥ
translated: By the same piece of sky that the sun moves during the day,

original: tenaiva niśi śītāṃśur aho daurgatyam etayoḥ // / //
analyzed: tena eva niśi śītāṃśuḥ aho daurgatyam etayoḥ  /
translated: by the same moon at night - alas, the misfortune of these two!

original: malīmasena dehena pratigeham upasthitāḥ /
analyzed: malīmasena dehena pratigeham upasthitāḥ
translated: Approaching every house with a dirty body,

original: ātmanaivātmakathakā vayaṃ vāyasavṛttayaḥ // / //
analyzed: ātmanā eva ātma kathakāḥ vayam vāyasa vṛttayaḥ
translated: We ourselves are the narrators of our own story, like crows in conduct.

original: bhūyād ato bahuvrīhi śāsanāśā mudhaiva me /
analyzed: bhūyāt atas bahuvrīhi śāsana āśā mudhā eva me
translated: From this, the bahuvrihi construction, my hope for the teachings is in vain.

original: pūrvāparāparāmarśād vimūḍhasyeva me matiḥ // / //
analyzed: pūrva apara aparāmarśāt vimūḍhasya iva me matiḥ
translated: My mind is confused, like one who is bewildered by the consideration of what is prior and what is subsequent.

original: iti dīnavrajyā ////
analyzed: iti dīna vrajyā
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the humble.

original: tato 'rthāntaranyāsavrajyā
analyzed: tatas ṛtha antara nyāsa vrajyā
translated: Then comes the chapter on the transference of meaning.

original: kālindyā dalitendranīlaśakalaśyāmāmbhaso 'ntarjale magnasyāñjanapuñjasañcayanibhasyāheḥ kuto 'nveṣaṇā /
analyzed: kālindyāḥ dalita indranīla śakala śyāma ambhasaḥ ntar jale magnasya añjana puñja sañcaya nibhasya aheḥ kutas nveṣaṇā
translated: When the water of the Yamuna, dark like a piece of sapphire, is split open, where is the search for a snake that has sunk in the water, resembling a heap of collyrium?

original: tārābhāḥ phaṇacakravālamaṇayo na syur yadi dyotino yair evonnatim āpnuvanti guṇinas tair eva yānty āpadam // / //
analyzed: tāra ābhāḥ phaṇa cakravāla maṇayaḥ na syuḥ yadi dyotinaḥ yaiḥ evā unnatim āpnuvanti guṇinaḥ taiḥ evā yānti āpadam  /
translated: If the jewels in the hood of the snake were not luminous like stars, by which it would attain loftiness, by those very things it would meet with calamity.

original: bhagnāśasya karaṇḍapiṇḍitatanor mlānendriyasya kṣudhā kṛtvākhur vivaraṃ svayaṃ nipatito naktaṃ mukhe bhoginaḥ /
analyzed: bhagna āśasya karaṇḍa piṇḍita tanoḥ mlāna indriyasya kṣudhā kṛtvā ākhuḥ vivaram svayam nipatitaḥ naktam mukhe bhoginaḥ
translated: The rat, having made a hole for itself, fell into the mouth of the snake at night, its body confined in a basket, its senses dull from hunger, its hopes shattered.

original: tṛptas tatpiśitena satvaram asau tenaiva yātaḥ pathā svasthās tiṣṭhata daivam eva jagataḥ śāntau kṣaye cākulam // / //
analyzed: tṛptaḥ tad piśitena sa tvaram asau tena eva yātaḥ pathā svasthāḥ tiṣṭhata daivam eva jagataḥ śāntau kṣaye ca ākulam  /
translated: Having been satisfied with its flesh, it quickly went back by the same path. Remain at ease, fate alone is agitated in the world's peace and destruction.

original: yasyāḥ kṛte nṛpatayas tṛṇavat tyajanti prāṇān priyān api parasparabaddhavairāḥ /
analyzed: yasyāḥ kṛte nṛpatayaḥ tṛṇa vat tyajanti prāṇān priyān api paraspara baddha vairāḥ
translated: For whose sake, kings abandon their dear lives, even becoming sworn enemies of each other, as if they were straw.

original: teṣām asṛk pibati saiva mahī hatānāṃ śrīḥ prāyaśo vikṛtim eti bahūpabhuktā // / //
analyzed: teṣām asṛk pibati sā eva mahī hatānām śrīḥ prāyaśas vikṛtim eti bahu upabhuktā  /
translated: That very earth drinks the blood of the slain, and prosperity, when enjoyed too much, generally becomes distorted.

original: rathasyaikaṃ cakraṃ bhujagayamitāḥ sapta turagāḥ nirālambo mārgaś caraṇarahitaḥ sārathir api /
analyzed: rathasya ekam cakram bhujaga yamitāḥ sapta turagāḥ nirālambaḥ mārgaḥ caraṇa rahitaḥ sārathiḥ api
translated: One wheel of the chariot, seven horses yoked like serpents, a path without support, and a charioteer devoid of feet.

original: ravir yāty evāntaṃ pratidinam apārasya nabhasaḥ kriyāsiddhiḥ sattve bhavati mahatāṃ nopakaraṇe // / //
analyzed: raviḥ yāti eva antam pratidinam apārasya nabhasaḥ kriyā siddhiḥ sattve bhavati mahatām na upakaraṇe
translated: The sun moves to the end of the boundless sky every day. The success of an action depends on the greatness of the being, not on the means.

original: vāgīśvarasya
analyzed: vāc īśvarasya
translated: Of Vāgīśvara (Lord of Speech)

original: paulastyaḥ katham anyadāraharaṇe doṣaṃ na vijñātavān kākutsthena kathaṃ na hemahariṇasyāsaṃbhavo lakṣitaḥ /
analyzed: paulastyaḥ katham anya dāra haraṇe doṣam na vijñātavān kākutsthena katham na hema hariṇasya asaṃbhavaḥ lakṣitaḥ
translated: How did Rāvaṇa not know the sin of abducting another's wife? How did Rāma not see the impossibility of the golden deer?

original: akṣāṇāṃ ca yudhiṣṭhireṇa mahatā jñāto na doṣaḥ kathaṃ pratyāsannavipattimūḍhamanasāṃ prāyo matiḥ kṣīyate // / //
analyzed: akṣāṇām ca yudhiṣṭhireṇa mahatā jñātaḥ na doṣaḥ katham pratyāsanna vipatti mūḍha manasām prāyas matiḥ kṣīyate  /
translated: How did Yudhiṣṭhira not know the sin of the dice in gambling? The mind of those whose misfortune is imminent is generally deluded and destroyed.

original: akārye tathyo vā bhavati vitathaḥ kāmam athavā tathāpy uccair dhāmnāṃ harati mahimānaṃ janaravaḥ /
analyzed: akārye tathyaḥ vā bhavati vitathaḥ kāmam athavā tathā api uccais dhāmnām harati mahimānam jana ravaḥ
translated: Whether true or false in an improper act, the loud cry of the people carries away the greatness of the high-souled.

original: tulottīrṇasyāpi prakaṭanihatāśeṣatamasoaḥ raves tādṛk tejo na hi bhavati kanyāṃ gata iti // / //
analyzed: tulā uttīrṇasya api prakaṭa nihata aśeṣa tamasoḥ raveḥ tādṛś tejaḥ na hi bhavati kanyām gataḥ iti
translated: Even when the sun has risen above the horizon, it does not have such brilliance as when it has reached the meridian.

original: kṛto yad ahnas tanimā himāgame laghīyasī yac ca nidāghaśarvarī /
analyzed: kṛtaḥ yat ahnaḥ tanimā hima āgame laghīyasī yat ca nidāgha śarvarī
translated: The day becomes thinner in winter, and the night of summer becomes shorter.

original: anena dṛṣṭāntayugena gamyate sadarthasaṃkocasamudyato vidhiḥ // / //
analyzed: anena dṛṣṭānta yugena gamyate sat artha saṃkoca samudyataḥ vidhiḥ
translated: By this pair of similes, it is understood that the creator is intent on contracting the true meaning.

original: pītāmbarāya tanayāṃ pradadau payodhis tatkālakūṭagaralaṃ ca digambarāya /
analyzed: pītāmbarāya tanayām pradadau payodhiḥ tad kālakūṭa garalam ca digambarāya
translated: The ocean gave his daughter to the one wearing yellow robes, and the poison halahala to the one naked.

original: tatrānayor vadata kasya guṇātirekaḥ prāyaḥ paricchadakṛtādara eva lokaḥ // / //
analyzed: tatra anayoḥ vadata kasya guṇa atirekaḥ prāyas paricchada kṛta ādaraḥ eva lokaḥ  /
translated: Tell me, which of these two has superior qualities? People generally respect the one who has a retinue.

original: kiṃ janmanā jagati kasyacid īkṣitena śaktyaiva yāti nijayā puruṣaḥ pratiṣṭhām /
analyzed: kim janmanā jagati kasyacid īkṣitena śaktyā eva yāti nijayā puruṣaḥ pratiṣṭhām
translated: What is the use of birth? A person attains his position by his own ability, even if he is not seen by anyone in the world.

original: śaktā hi kūpam api śoṣayituṃ na kumbhāḥ kumbhodbhavena punar ambudhir eva pītaḥ // / //
analyzed: śaktāḥ hi kūpam api śoṣayitum na kumbhāḥ kumbhodbhavena punar ambudhiḥ eva pītaḥ  /
translated: For, pots are not able to dry up even a well, but the one born from a pot drank up the ocean.

original: puṃsaḥ svarūpavinirūpaṇam eva kāryaṃ tajjanmabhūmiguṇadoṣakathā vṛthaiva /
analyzed: puṃsaḥ svarūpa vinirūpaṇam eva kāryam tad janma bhūmi guṇa doṣa kathā vṛthā eva
translated: One should only determine the nature of a person, the talk of the virtues and faults of his birthplace is useless.

original: kaḥ kālakūṭam abhinandati sāgarotthaṃ ko vāravindam abhinindati paṅkajātam // / //
analyzed: kaḥ kālakūṭam abhinandati sāgara uttham kaḥ vā aravindam abhinindati paṅka jātam
translated: Who praises the poison halahala born from the ocean? Who criticizes the lotus born from mud?

original: khalvāṭo divaseśvarasya kiraṇaiḥ saṃtāpito mūrdhani chāyām ātapavairiṇīm anusaran bilvasya mūlaṃ gataḥ /
analyzed: khalvāṭaḥ divaseśvarasya kiraṇaiḥ saṃtāpitaḥ mūrdhani chāyām ātapa vairiṇīm anusaran bilvasya mūlam gataḥ
translated: Khāṇḍikya, scorched on his head by the rays of the sun, following the shade, an enemy of the sun, has gone to the foot of a bilva tree.

original: tatrāpy āśu kadācid eva patatā bilvena bhagnaṃ śiraḥ prāyo gacchati yatra bhāgyarahitas tatrāpadāṃ bhājanam // / //
analyzed: tatra api āśu kadācid eva patatā bilvena bhagnam śiraḥ prāyas gacchati yatra bhāgya rahitaḥ tatra āpadām bhājanam  /
translated: There too, his head was quickly broken by a bilva fruit falling down. Generally, where a luckless person goes, he becomes a receptacle of misfortune.

original: alaṃkāraḥ śaṅkākaranarakapālaḥ parikaraḥ praśīrṇāṅgo bhṛṅgī vasu ca vṛṣa eko bahuvayāḥ /
analyzed: alaṃkāraḥ śaṅkā kara naraka pālaḥ parikaraḥ praśīrṇa aṅgaḥ bhṛṅgī vasu ca vṛṣaḥ ekaḥ bahu vayāḥ
translated: Śiva's ornament is a human skull that causes fear, his retinue is the scattered-limbed Bhṛṅgī, and his wealth is a single bull of many years.

original: avastheyaṃ sthāṇor api bhavati yatrāmaraguror vidhau vakre mūrdhni sthitavati vayaṃ ke punar amī // / //
analyzed: avastheyam sthāṇoḥ api bhavati yatra amara guroḥ vidhau vakre mūrdhni sthitavati vayam ke punar amī  /
translated: In this state, even Śiva, the preceptor of the gods, becomes so, when fate, with its crooked head, is present. What then are we?

original: na saṃbandopādhiṃ dadhata iha dākṣiṇyanidhayaḥ prahṛṣṭapremāṇāṃ sa hi sahaja eṣām udayate /
analyzed: na saṃbanda upādhim dadhataḥ iha dākṣiṇya nidhayaḥ prahṛṣṭa premāṇām sa hi sahajaḥ eṣām udayate
translated: The repositories of courtesy do not bear the condition of relationship here; that is innate in them, who are full of love.

original: ka ete saṃbandhān malayamarutaś cūtataravo yad etān ālabhya pratiparurudānaṃ janayati // / //
analyzed: ke ete saṃbandhāt malaya marutaḥ cūta taravaḥ yat etān ālabhya pratiparurudānam janayati  /
translated: Who are these related to the Malaya wind and mango trees, that by touching them, they generate mutual affection?

original: lokottaraṃ caritam arpayati pratiṣṭhāṃ puṃsaḥ kulaṃ na hi nimittam udāttatāyāḥ /
analyzed: lokottaram caritam arpayati pratiṣṭhām puṃsaḥ kulam na hi nimittam udātta tāyāḥ
translated: The conduct of a person, which is beyond the world, gives rise to his greatness, not his family, which is merely a cause.

original: vātāpitāpanamuneḥ kalaśāt prasūtir līlāyitaṃ punar amuṣya samudrapānam // / //
analyzed: vātāpi tāpana muneḥ kalaśāt prasūtiḥ līlāyitam punar amuṣya samudra pānam  /
translated: The birth of this sage from the pot of Vātāpi, and again his playful act of drinking the ocean,

original: sthalīnāṃ dagdhānām upari mṛgatṛṣṇānusaraṇāt tṛṣārtaḥ śāraṅgo viramati na khinne 'pi vapuṣi /
analyzed: sthalīnām dagdhānām upari mṛgatṛṣṇā anusaraṇāt tṛṣā ārtaḥ śāraṅgaḥ viramati na khinne vapuṣi
translated: The thirsty deer, exhausted though his body be, does not cease from pursuing the mirage over the burnt ground.

original: ajānānas tattvaṃ na sa mṛgayate 'nyāṃ ca sarasīm abhūmau pratyāśā na hi phalati vighnaṃ ca kurute // / //🔽kiṃ kūrmasya bharavyathā na vapuṣi kṣmāṃ na kṣipaty eṣa yat kiṃ vā nāsti pariśramo dinakarasyāste na yan niścalaḥ /
analyzed: a jānānaḥ tattvam na sa mṛgayate ca sarasīm abhūmau pratyāśā na hi phalati vighnam ca kurute  / kim kūrmasya bhara vyathā na vapuṣi kṣmām na kṣipati eṣa yat kim vā nā asti pariśramaḥ dinakarasya āste na yat niścalaḥ
translated: Not knowing the truth, he does not seek another lake. For hope in a non-existent place does not bear fruit, but creates an obstacle.🔽Is there no pain in the tortoise's body from the weight, that it does not throw itself on the ground? Or is there no fatigue in the sun, that it does not rest?

original: kiṃ tv aṅgīkṛtam utsṛjan kṛpaṇavad ślāghyo jano lajjate nirvyūḍhiḥ pratipannavastuṣu satām ekaṃ batāho vratam // / //
analyzed: kim tu aṅgīkṛtam utsṛjan kṛpaṇa vat ślāghyaḥ janaḥ lajjate nirvyūḍhiḥ pratipanna vastuṣu satām ekam bata aho vratam  /  /
translated: But a person who abandons what he has undertaken is to be pitied, and is ashamed. The one vow of the good is to carry through to the end what they have undertaken.

original: svacchāśayo bhavati ko 'pi janaḥ prakṛtyā saṅgaḥ satām abhijanaś ca na hetur atra /
analyzed: su accha āśayaḥ bhavati kaḥ pi janaḥ prakṛtyā saṅgaḥ satām abhijanaḥ ca na hetuḥ atra
translated: Some person becomes pure-hearted by nature, and association with the good, and noble birth are not the cause here.

original: dugdhābdhilabdhajanano harakandharāsthaḥ svāṃ kālatāṃ tyajati jātu na kālakūṭaḥ // / //
analyzed: dugdhābdhi labdha jananaḥ hara kandhara sthaḥ svām kāla tām tyajati jātu na kālakūṭaḥ  /
translated: The Kālakūṭa poison, born from the milk-ocean, residing on Śiva's throat, never abandons its own nature of being black.

original: vāsaś carma vibhūṣaṇaṃ śavaśiro bhikṣāṇatenāśanaṃ gaur ekaḥ sa ca lāṅgale 'py akuśalas tanmātrasāraṃ dhanam /🔽śarvasyety avagamya yāti vimukhī ratnālayaṃ jāhnavī kaṣṭaṃ durgatikasya jīvitam aho dārair api tyajyate // / //
analyzed: vāsaḥ carma vibhūṣaṇam śava śiraḥ bhikṣā āṇatena aśanam gauḥ ekaḥ sa ca lāṅgale pi akuśalaḥ tad mātra sāram dhanam  śarvasya iti avagamya yāti vimukhī ratna ālayam jāhnavī kaṣṭam durgatikasya jīvitam aho dāraiḥ api tyajyate  /
translated: His clothes are a skin, his ornament a human skull, his food alms begged, and his only possession a cow that is unskilled even in ploughing.🔽Knowing this is Shiva's, the Ganges turns away and goes to the abode of jewels. Alas! The life of one in misfortune is abandoned even by his wife.

original: kaivartakarkaśakaragrahaṇacyuto 'pi jāle punar nipatitaḥ śapharo varākaḥ /
analyzed: kaivarta karkaśa kara grahaṇa cyutaḥ pi jāle punar nipatitaḥ śapharaḥ varākaḥ
translated: Even though slipping from the grasp of the fisherman's rough hands, the poor fish falls back into the net.

original: daivāt tato 'pi galito gilito bakena vāme vidhau vada kathaṃ vyasanasya śāntiḥ // / //
analyzed: daivāt galitaḥ gilitaḥ bakena vāme vidhau vada katham vyasanasya śāntiḥ  /
translated: By chance, escaping from there too, it is swallowed by a heron. When fate is adverse, how can there be peace for misfortune?

original: khanati na khuraiḥ kṣoṇīpṛṣṭhaṃ na nardati sādaraṃ prakṛtipuruṣaṃ dṛṣṭvaivāgre na kupyati gām api /
analyzed: khanati na khuraiḥ kṣoṇī pṛṣṭham na nardati sa ādaram prakṛti puruṣam dṛṣṭvā eva agre na kupyati gām api
translated: He does not dig the ground with his hooves, does not bellow respectfully, and does not get angry at the cow even on seeing the natural male in front.

original: vahati tu dhuraṃ dhuryo dhairyād anuddhatakandharo jagati kṛtinaḥ kāryaudāryād pt parān atiśerate // / //
analyzed: vahati tu dhuram dhuryaḥ dhairyāt anuddhata kandharaḥ jagati kṛtinaḥ kārya audāryāt parān atiśerate  /
translated: But the ox bears the load with patience, his neck not raised haughtily. In the world, the virtuous surpass others by the greatness of their deeds.

original: śiraḥ śārvaṃ svargād pt paśupatiśirastaḥ kṣitibhṛtaṃ mahīdhrād uttuṅgād avanitalam asmāc ca jaladhim /
analyzed: śiraḥ śārvam svargāt paśupati śirastaḥ kṣitibhṛtam mahīdhrāt uttuṅgāt avani talam asmāt ca jaladhim
translated: The head of Shiva descended from heaven, the king from the head of Shiva, the mountain from the lofty mountain, and the ocean from the earth.

original: adho 'dho gaṅgāvad vayam upagatā dūram athavā padabhraṃśetānāṃ bhavati vinipātaḥ śatamukhaḥ // / //
analyzed: adhas dhas gaṅgā vat vayam upagatāḥ dūram athavā bhavati vinipātaḥ śata mukhaḥ  /
translated: Or, perhaps we have gone far down like the Ganges. In any case, for those who have lost their position, downfall has a hundred doors.

original: kvāpi kasya ca kuto 'pi kāraṇāc cittavṛttir iha kiṃ guṇāguṇaiḥ /
analyzed: kvāpi kasya ca kutas pi kāraṇāt citta vṛttiḥ iha kim guṇa aguṇaiḥ
translated: Where, of whom, for what reason, does the state of mind arise here, by what qualities or faults?

original: unnataṃ yad avadhīrya bhūdharaṃ nīcam abdhim abhiyāti jāhnavī // / //
analyzed: unnatam yat bhūdharam nīcam abdhim abhiyāti jāhnavī
translated: Having disregarded the lofty mountain, the Ganges goes down to the low ocean.

original: sarasi bahuśas tārācchāyāṃ daśan parivañcitaḥ kumudaviṭapānveṣī haṃso niśāsu vicakṣaṇaḥ /
analyzed: sarasi bahuśas tārā chāyām daśan parivañcitaḥ kumuda viṭapa anveṣī haṃsaḥ niśāsu vicakṣaṇaḥ
translated: The wise swan, seeing the reflection of the stars many times in the lake, seeking the jasmine creeper, is deceived at night.

original: na daśati punas tārāśaṅkī divāpi sitotpalaṃ kuhakacakito lokaḥ satye 'py apāyam avekṣate // / //
analyzed: na daśati punar tārā āśaṅkī divā api sita utpalam kuhaka cakitaḥ lokaḥ satye pi apāyam avekṣate  /
translated: Suspecting the stars, it does not peck at the white lotus even during the day. The world, frightened by the deceitful, looks for danger even in truth.

original: asthānābhiniveśī prāyo jaḍa eva bhavati no vidvān /
analyzed: a sthāna abhiniveśī prāyas jaḍaḥ eva bhavati no vidvān
translated: One who is attached to the impossible is mostly dull-witted, not wise.

original: bālād anyaḥ ko 'mbhasi jighṛkṣatīndoḥ sphuradbimbam // / //
analyzed: bālāt anyaḥ kaḥ mbhasi jighṛkṣati indoḥ sphurat bimbam
translated: Who else but a child would try to grasp the shining orb of the moon in water?

original: nirguṇam apy anuraktaṃ prāyo na samāśritaṃ jahati santaḥ /
analyzed: nirguṇam api anuraktam prāyas na samāśritam jahati santaḥ
translated: The good do not abandon even an affectionate one devoid of qualities, if he is dependent on them.

original: sahavṛddhikṣayabhājaṃ vahati śaśāṅkaḥ kalaṅkam api // / //
analyzed: saha vṛddhi kṣaya bhājam vahati śaśāṅkaḥ kalaṅkam api
translated: The moon bears the spot, which shares its waxing and waning.

original: avikāriṇam api sajjanam aniśam anāryaḥ prabādhate 'tyartham /
analyzed: avikāriṇam api sat janam aniśam anāryaḥ prabādhate tyartham
translated: Even a good person who is unchanging, the ignoble greatly afflicts him constantly.

original: kamalinyā kim apakṛtaṃ himasya yas tāṃ sadā dahati // / //
analyzed: kamalinyā kim apakṛtam himasya yaḥ tām sadā dahati
translated: What wrong has the lotus done to the snow, that it should always burn it?

original: bhayaṃ yad dhanur īśvarasya śiśinā yaj jāmadagnyo hatas tyaktā yena guror girā vasumatī baddho yad ambhonidhiḥ /
analyzed: bhayam yat dhanuḥ īśvarasya śiśinā yat jāmadagnyaḥ hataḥ tyaktā yena guroḥ girā vasumatī baddhaḥ yat ambhonidhiḥ
translated: The fear of Shiva, the wielder of the bow, that Jamadagni's son was killed by the cold weapon, that he abandoned the earth at the word of his guru, that he bound the ocean,

original: ekaikaṃ daśakandharakṣayakṛto rāmasya kiṃ varṇyate daivaṃ varṇaya yena so 'pi sahasā nītaḥ kathāśeṣatām // / //
analyzed: ekaikam daśa kandhara kṣaya kṛtaḥ rāmasya kim varṇyate daivam varṇaya yena saḥ pi sahasā nītaḥ kathā śeṣa tām  /
translated: each of these is the cause of Rama's destruction of the ten-headed one. What is to be described? Describe fate, by which he too was suddenly reduced to a mere story.

original: śaśinam uditaṃ lekhāmātraṃ namanti na cetaraṃ gaganasaritaṃ dhatte mūrdhnā haro na nagātmajām /
analyzed: śaśinam uditam lekhā mātram namanti na ca itaram gagana saritam dhatte mūrdhnā haraḥ na naga ātmajām
translated: They bow to the rising moon, just a line, and not to the other, Shiva does not hold the daughter of the mountain on his head, the celestial Ganga.

original: tribhuvanapatir lakṣmīṃ tyaktvā hariḥ priyagopikaḥ paricitaguṇadveṣī loko navaṃ navam icchati // / //
analyzed: tribhuvana patiḥ lakṣmīm tyaktvā hariḥ priya gopikaḥ paricita guṇa dveṣī lokaḥ navam navam icchati  /
translated: Hari, the lord of the three worlds, abandoning Lakshmi, fond of cowherdesses, the people, hating known qualities, desire something new and new.

original: upaśamaphalād vidyābījād pt phalaṃ dhanam icchatāṃ bhavati viphalaḥ prārambho yat tad atra kim adbhutam /
analyzed: upaśama phalāt vidyā bījāt phalam dhanam icchatām bhavati viphalaḥ prārambhaḥ yat tat atra kim adbhutam
translated: For those who desire wealth, the fruit of learning, the seed of which is tranquility, becomes fruitless. What wonder is there in that?

original: niyataviṣayāḥ sarve bhāvā na yānti hi vikriyāṃ janayitum alaṃ śāler bījaṃ na jātu javāṅkuram // / //
analyzed: niyata viṣayāḥ sarve bhāvāḥ na yānti hi vikriyām janayitum alam śāleḥ bījam na jātu java aṅkuram
translated: All things have fixed objects and do not change. The seed of rice is not able to produce a barley sprout.

original: tṛṣārtaiḥ sāraṅgaiḥ pratijaladharaṃ bhūri virutaṃ ghanair muktā dhārāḥ sapadi payasas tān prati muhuḥ /
analyzed: tṛṣā ārtaiḥ sāraṅgaiḥ prati jaladharam bhūri virutam ghanaiḥ muktāḥ dhārāḥ sapadi payasaḥ tān prati muhur
translated: The thirsty deer, crying out to the clouds for water, are immediately met by the clouds pouring down rain upon them.

original: khagānāṃ ke meghāḥ ka iha vihagā vā jalamucām ayācyo nārtānām anupakaraṇīyo na mahatām // / //
analyzed: khagānām ke meghāḥ ke iha vihagāḥ vā jalamucām a yācyaḥ na ārtānām an upakaraṇīyaḥ na mahatām  /
translated: Which are the clouds and which the birds? Which are the birds and which the clouds? The distressed ask nothing, the great give everything.

original: bhartṛhareḥ /
analyzed: bhartṛhareḥ
translated: Of Bhartṛhari.

original: Spdśā /pa / / Skmsa /u /ka /
analyzed: spdśāpa
translated: Spardhā.

original: payas tejo vāyur gaganam avanir viśvam api vā svayaṃ viṣṇus tasya tridaśajayinaḥ kiṃ na sukaram /
analyzed: payaḥ tejaḥ vāyuḥ gaganam avaniḥ viśvam api vā svayam viṣṇuḥ tasya tridaśa jayinaḥ kim na sukaram
